/news/world-middle-east-35812371.title: BBC News - Syria conflict: Russia 'to continue air strikes' after withdrawal
/news/world-middle-east-35812371.summary: Russia will continue air strikes on "terrorist targets" in Syria, despite announcing the withdrawal of most of its forces, officials say.
/news/world-middle-east-35812371.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/5dfcaa7a-732a-e041-8db7-4eab212eb300"><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="88777593">    <caption>Video showed the first group of Russian jets leaving Syria according to Russia's Defence Ministry</caption>  </video><paragraph role="introduction">Russia will continue air strikes in Syria despite the withdrawal of most of its forces, a senior official has said.</paragraph><paragraph>Deputy Defence Minister Nikolay Pankov said it was too early to speak of defeating terrorism, after a campaign that has bolstered Syria's government.</paragraph><paragraph>Russian forces started leaving Syria on Tuesday after Monday's surprise announcement by President Vladimir Putin. Some have now landed in Russia.</paragraph><paragraph>A second day of peace talks is being held aimed at resolving the conflict.</paragraph><paragraph>UN Special Envoy Staffan de Mistura, who is mediating in the talks, welcomed the Russian decision.</paragraph><paragraph>"The announcement by President Putin on the very day of the beginning of this round of Intra-Syrian Talks in Geneva is a significant development, which we hope will have a positive impact on the progress of the negotiations," he said.</paragraph><image id="76020974"/><crosshead>More on the Syria conflict</crosshead>  <list type="unordered">    <listItem><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35813828 --><link><caption>IS: The full story</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35695648"/></link></listItem>    <listItem><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35813829 --><link><caption>Why has fighting gone on for five years?</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35806229"/></link></listItem>    <listItem><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35813826 --><link><caption>How Putin took command in Syria</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-35787739"/></link></listItem>    <listItem><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35813002 --><link><caption>Russia's 'peace mission' in Syria</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35721075"/></link></listItem>    <listItem><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35813823 --><link><caption>Story of the conflict</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-26116868"/></link></listItem>    <listItem><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35813825 --><link><caption>Tide turns Assad's way</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35562943"/></link></listItem>    <listItem><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35813830 --><link><caption>Russian media hail withdrawal</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35812761"/></link></listItem>  </list><image id="76020974"/><paragraph>Russian defence ministry video showed the first group of aircraft taking off from Hmeimim air base in Syria on Tuesday morning and in flight.</paragraph><paragraph>Hours later, Russian TV showed planes arriving in the southern Russian city of Voronezh, where they were greeted on the tarmac by priests and crowds waving balloons.</paragraph><paragraph>Su-24 tactical bombers, Su-25 attack fighters, Su-34 strike fighters and helicopters were returning home, the TV said.</paragraph><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="88779004">    <caption>Syrian kids explain the war</caption>  </video><paragraph>But Mr Pankov said a Russian air group would remain.</paragraph><paragraph>"Certain positive results have been achieved... However, it is too early to talk about victory over terrorism. A Russian air group has the task of continuing to strike terrorist facilities," he was quoted by Ria news agency as saying.</paragraph><image id="76020974"/><image id="88779042"/><paragraph>The war in Syria has raged for five years and claimed the lives of more than a quarter of a million people. Millions have fled the conflict, but nearly 18 million people still live in the war-torn country - so what is life like for them?</paragraph><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35813827 --><link><caption>Find out here</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/resources/idt-841ebc3a-1be9-493b-8800-2c04890e8fc9"/></link></paragraph><image id="76020974"/><paragraph>Another senior official, upper house defence committee head Viktor Ozerov, said as many as two battalions - some 800 servicemen - could remain in Syria after the withdrawal to guard Hmeimim and the naval base at Tartous, Interfax news agency reported.</paragraph><paragraph>Military advisers training Syrian government troops would also stay, he added.</paragraph><paragraph>Meanwhile Kremlin chief-of-staff Sergey Ivanov said Russia would keep its advanced S-400 surface-to-air missile system in place.</paragraph><paragraph>"We are leaving completely reliable cover for the remaining contingent... To effectively ensure security, including from the air, we need the most modern air defence systems," Russian media quoted him as saying.</paragraph><image id="88559650"/><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35813824 --><link><caption>The Russian force reduction was announced</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35807689"/></link> during a meeting on Monday between Mr Putin and his defence and foreign ministers. </paragraph><paragraph>Russia is a key ally of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, and his office sought to reject speculation there was a rift between the two countries, saying the move was mutually agreed.</paragraph><paragraph>It has received a guarded welcome from Western diplomats and the Syrian opposition.</paragraph><crosshead>War crimes report</crosshead><paragraph>The Russian air campaign started last September, tipping the balance in favour of the Syrian government and allowing it to recapture territory from rebels, but on Tuesday the defence ministry announced the withdrawal.</paragraph><paragraph>It is not clear how many military personnel Russia has deployed, but US estimates suggest the number ranges from 3,000 to 6,000, AP reports.</paragraph><paragraph>Russia had long insisted its bombing campaign only targeted terrorist groups but Western powers had complained the raids hit political opponents of President Assad.</paragraph><paragraph>In a statement, the Syrian government said the plan was agreed between the two countries.</paragraph><paragraph>Most participants in the Syria conflict agreed to a cessation of hostilities, which has been largely holding despite reports of some violations on all sides.</paragraph><paragraph>Meanwhile, the UN Commission of Inquiry on Syria has presented its report on war crimes committed by all sides in Syria's war to the UN Human Rights Council in Geneva.</paragraph><paragraph>Its chairman Paulo Pinheiro said the task of pursuing war criminals should not wait for a final peace agreement as there was now "hope of an end in sight".</paragraph><image id="76020974"/><crosshead>Why did Russia launch an air campaign in Syria?</crosshead><paragraph>Russia is one of President Bashar al-Assad's most important international backers and the survival of his government is critical to maintaining Russian interests in Syria. Russia has a key naval facility which it leases at the port of Tartous and has forces at the Hmeimim airbase in Latakia.</paragraph><paragraph>In September 2015, with rebel forces advancing on Latakia, Russian forces launched an air campaign which President Vladimir Putin said was aimed at "stabilising" the Syrian government and creating conditions for "a political compromise" that would end the five-year conflict.</paragraph><crosshead>What does Russia say its intervention achieved?</crosshead><paragraph>In March 2016, Mr Putin ordered the "main part" of Russia's forces to withdraw from Syria, saying their mission had "on the whole" been accomplished. </paragraph><paragraph>Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu said Russian aircraft had flown more than 9,000 sorties over almost six months, killing more than 2,000 "bandits" and helping Syrian government forces regain control of 10,000 sq km (3,860 sq miles) of territory, including 400 population centres.</paragraph><paragraph>The claims have not yet been independently verified, but it is clear the air campaign turned the tide of the war in favour of Mr Assad, allowing Syrian government ground forces to regain territory around Latakia, in the southern province of Deraa and around the divided northern city of Aleppo.</paragraph><crosshead>What do critics say?</crosshead><paragraph>Moscow stressed that its air strikes only targeted "terrorists", but activists said Russian aircraft had mainly bombed Western-backed rebel groups and civilian areas.</paragraph><paragraph>In December, Amnesty International said Russian aircraft appeared to have directly attacked civilians by striking residential areas with no evident military target, which it warned might amount to war crimes. Russia's defence ministry dismissed the report as containing "fake information".</paragraph><paragraph>However, the UK-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights reported in early March that 1,733 civilians, including 429 children, had been killed in Russian air strikes, along with some 1,492 rebels and members of the al-Qaeda-affiliated al-Nusra Front, and 1,183 Islamic State (IS) militants.</paragraph></body>
/news/world-middle-east-35812371.shortFormBody: <shortFormBody xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/5dfcaa7a-732a-e041-8db7-4eab212eb300"><paragraph>Russia will continue air strikes in Syria despite the withdrawal of most of its forces, a senior official has said.</paragraph><paragraph>Deputy Defence Minister Nikolay Pankov said it was too early to speak of defeating terrorism, after a campaign that has bolstered Syria's government.</paragraph><paragraph>Russian forces started leaving Syria on Tuesday after Monday's surprise announcement by President Vladimir Putin. Some have now landed in Russia.</paragraph><paragraph>A second day of peace talks is being held aimed at resolving the conflict.</paragraph></shortFormBody>

/news/world-us-canada-35809507.title: BBC News - PJ Crowley: Putin's payoff in Syria
/news/world-us-canada-35809507.summary: Vladimir Putin has made Russia an indispensable player in the Syrian conflict, in contrast to President Barack Obama, writes PJ Crowley.
/news/world-us-canada-35809507.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/f9e93cf6-f05b-534f-9a89-3336d45df6a5"><image id="88773702"/><paragraph role="introduction">Vladimir Putin's surprise announcement of a Russian military pullback from Syria underscores how his country has played a decisive role in the conflict, frequently outmanoeuvring the US, writes PJ Crowley.</paragraph><paragraph>There are no winning hands in the great game being played in Syria, but Vladimir Putin has reaped a positive return from his military intervention to shore up the position of President Bashar al-Assad's government.</paragraph><paragraph>His gamble could still be a loser over the long term, but he currently has command of the table and over what happens next. </paragraph><paragraph>Mr Putin's combination of aggression and finesse is in sharp contrast to his American counterpart. Barack Obama has carefully guarded his chips, seeing little to be gained with the lousy cards in Syria.</paragraph><paragraph>While the United States is leading a limited military campaign against the Islamic State, Mr Obama has offered little more than the status quo ante when it comes to Mr Assad.</paragraph><image id="76020974"/><crosshead>More on the Syria conflict</crosshead>  <list type="unordered">    <listItem><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35812994 --><link><caption>Life and death in Syria</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/resources/idt-841ebc3a-1be9-493b-8800-2c04890e8fc9"/></link></listItem>    <listItem><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35812995 --><link><caption>IS: The full story</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35695648"/></link></listItem>    <listItem><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35812996 --><link><caption>Why has fighting gone on for five years?</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35806229"/></link></listItem>    <listItem><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35812998 --><link><caption>Russia's 'peace mission' in Syria</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35721075"/></link></listItem>    <listItem><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35812999 --><link><caption>Story of the conflict</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-26116868"/></link></listItem>    <listItem><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35813000 --><link><caption>Tide turns Assad's way</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35562943"/></link></listItem>  </list><image id="76020974"/><paragraph>Mr Obama has called for Mr Assad to step down, but there has never been a real strategy behind that rhetoric. Mr Putin and Mr Obama are actually playing two interrelated but different games. Success in each game is the same - a functioning Syrian state that is not a safe haven for extremists. </paragraph><paragraph>Their paths are vastly different. One envisages the survival of the existing Syrian regime, with some symbolic accommodation with its political opposition. The other one involves an inclusive political process that results in genuine power-sharing. </paragraph><image id="88773706"/><paragraph>Given the events of the past six months, Mr Putin is far closer to his goal than Mr Obama. Mr Obama insists that Syria does not represent a competition between the two leaders, but it is becoming increasingly hard to view it any other way.</paragraph><paragraph>While Mr Obama is fond of calling the United States the indispensable nation, it is President Putin who has repeatedly made himself indispensable in Syria.</paragraph><paragraph>First, after what he viewed as a fiasco in Libya, he made sure that the United Nations would not sanction a comparable intervention in Syria. There has been no international responsibility to protect the Syrian people from their dictator as there was in Libya. </paragraph><paragraph>Second, after Mr Obama threatened military action in response to Syria's crossing of his red line over the use of chemical weapons, Mr Putin imposed on Mr Assad to yield his chemical weapons stocks. However, this provided a de facto green light to attack the opposition through conventional means. </paragraph><paragraph>Finally, while Mr Obama hesitated at the use of military force, requesting congressional approval that would likely not have materialised, Mr Putin intervened decisively. </paragraph><image id="88773992"/><paragraph>Where Mr Obama's contemplated use of military force would not have affected the military balance in the Syrian civil war, Mr Putin fundamentally changed at least one crucial fact on the ground. </paragraph><paragraph>Mr Obama's policy has been based until now on the presumption that Mr Assad's days are numbered. That may still be true but, thanks to Putin, the number is getting larger not smaller. </paragraph><paragraph>Mr Obama is right when he said that Syria cannot return to where it was before the civil war. He is also right when he says that the conflict will not end as long as Mr Assad remains in power. </paragraph><paragraph>But given that Mr Assad for the moment is not going anywhere, it is very likely that the political process that resumes this week in Syria is not going anywhere either. </paragraph><paragraph>As Mr Obama <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35809508 --><link><caption>suggested in a recent interview</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2016/04/the-obama-doctrine/471525/"/></link> with Jeffrey Goldberg of The Atlantic, he does not see Mr Putin's intervention as a success, but rather as an over-extension. </paragraph><paragraph>Washington was content to play Huck Finn and let Moscow be Tom Sawyer and paint the fence. </paragraph><paragraph>The problem with the White House analogy is that in regional geo-politics, who actually paints the fence matters. Mr Obama over the past three years has been far too dismissive of the importance of the perceived decline in the credibility of American power.</paragraph><image id="88773710"/><paragraph>Mr Obama suggests he wants to leave a "clean barn" for his successor. In fact, his successor will need to rebuild international trust and confidence in American leadership just as he did - albeit from a very different place. </paragraph><paragraph>In 2009, the United States was accused of doing too much, with dire consequences in Iraq. Today, the United States is accused of not doing enough, with dire consequences in Syria. </paragraph><paragraph>While Mr Obama has never believed that he needed to solve the tragedy in Syria - he has consistently viewed it as someone else's civil war - in all likelihood his successor will have to do more. </paragraph><paragraph>US efforts to date have degraded the Islamic State, but it is questionable whether it can be defeated through the existing limited levels of air power and special operations forces.</paragraph><paragraph>Mr Obama has been reluctant to do more, understandably fearing that greater involvement might exacerbate the extremist threat to the US and its allies. </paragraph><paragraph>While the current operational pause has had a greater effect on the ground than anticipated, the next president will likely inherit the Syrian civil war and find a solution to end it. </paragraph><paragraph>Its dangerous ripple effects cannot be ignored, even if the conflict itself does not represent an existential threat. </paragraph><paragraph>What is unclear is whether Mr Putin's gamble has made a solution to the Syrian conflict harder or easier to achieve. It could be either one.</paragraph><paragraph><italic>PJ Crowley is a former US Assistant Secretary of State, now a professor of practice and fellow at the George Washington University Institute of Public Diplomacy & Global Communication.</italic></paragraph></body>

/news/world-middle-east-35802955.title: BBC News - How do Syrian children explain the war?
/news/world-middle-east-35802955.summary: Syrian children explain in stark terms how the war has changed their lives, including the loved ones that they have lost.
/news/world-middle-east-35802955.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/e4dfba91-23fe-2143-8c3d-c8f95b74c72b"><paragraph>On the fifth anniversary of the Syrian war, we ask children to explain how the war has affected them.</paragraph><paragraph>Some can only remember war and many have lost loved ones. Some have even been maimed.</paragraph><paragraph>This is the Syrian war told through the eyes of kids.</paragraph></body>

/news/world-middle-east-35789827.title: BBC News - Syria: A different country after five years of war
/news/world-middle-east-35789827.summary: BBC Chief International Correspondent Lyse Doucet looks back over five years of Syria's war and asks if the country is lost.
/news/world-middle-east-35789827.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/5df22a69-cff2-b94d-99fa-ed00d1945451"><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="88732480">    <caption>The BBC's chief international correspondent Lyse Doucet was in Deraa five years ago and has returned to see what civil war has done to the country and its people.</caption>  </video><paragraph role="introduction">Its first moments were fleeting and furtive, small but significant.</paragraph><paragraph>Young women unfurled protest banners from their handbags on a busy Damascus street, then quickly retreated. Teenage boys sprayed graffiti on a school wall in the southern city of Deraa.</paragraph><paragraph>Five years on, Syria's uprising is now the longest, most vicious conflict in what was first poetically depicted as the Arab Spring. </paragraph><paragraph>Many young activists, who first raised their heads and voices to call for political reform are now disenchanted, detained, displaced or dead. </paragraph><paragraph>Their cries have long since been drowned out by the deafening roar of a destructive war which sets a multiplying array of opposition forces against the Syrian army and its militias.  </paragraph><paragraph>On both sides, there's the most bewildering array of outside actors ever seen in any war, anywhere. And then there's the so-called Islamic State (IS).</paragraph><paragraph>Syria's war is now everyone's war. </paragraph><image id="88735724"/><crosshead>'All people are afraid'</crosshead><paragraph>Syria, before this war, was a middle-income Arab state of exceptional hospitality, exquisite cuisine, fabled charm - and infamous repression. </paragraph><paragraph>It was a place in the 1990s where, in the wake of the Soviet Union's jarring collapse, I was constantly told "revolution is not for us, we prefer Syria to evolve". A former government official recently admitted to me it meant "change so slow, it was glacial".</paragraph><paragraph>Over the past five years of reporting on a extraordinary country's astonishing turn, many small moments told a much bigger story.</paragraph><paragraph>In 2011 among crowds milling around a mosque after Friday prayers, a young man nervously <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35789828 --><link><caption>thrust a crumpled message into a colleague's hand</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-19758687"/></link>. It read: "Thank you. But no one can meet with you because the army is in the street. All people are afraid."  </paragraph><image id="88735720"/><paragraph>"Look down the road," another man whispered tersely in my ear, as intelligence attired in track suits slipped through an anxious crowd in the Damascus neighbourhood of Barzeh. Down the road, soldiers stood in wait and snipers were in sight.</paragraph><paragraph>Six months later, a people too afraid to even to say they were afraid had lost their fear. Down that same road, residents beckoned us inside a warren of winding lanes filled with chants of protestors. Deep inside, a house belonging to the Free Syrian Army was peppered with shrapnel, blackened by fire. </paragraph><paragraph>Another six months on, that road was sealed off and silent. The army was back in charge.</paragraph><crosshead>Funerals and massacres</crosshead><paragraph>As the years dragged on, the momentum of battle shifted between sides. </paragraph><paragraph>Everyone paid a price.</paragraph><paragraph>In 2012, in the hilly heartland of President Assad's Alawite community in Latakia, entire villages turned out virtually every day, sometimes three times a day, to bury young soldiers returning in coffins from front lines.</paragraph><paragraph>My colleague Phil Goodwin, who filmed our reports on most trips, asked a man lingering by a graveside how such a warm people could have descended into such darkness. "There's a wild beast within all of us," he sighed.</paragraph><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="65387738">    <caption>The BBC's Lyse Doucet: "This is a war crime"</caption>  </video><paragraph>The worst in Syria has been the worst no one could have imagined.</paragraph><paragraph>In 2013 in the village of Haswiya, where news spread of a massacre, <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35789829 --><link><caption>we opened a door on a sprawling compound</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-21073447"/></link> to find houses of horror. </paragraph><paragraph>Charred bodies sprawled inside rooms and slumped across doorways, left where they'd been shot and burned. Washing hung on the clothes line and food was still in the oven.</paragraph><paragraph>Soldiers who escorted us blamed fighters of the al-Nusra Front. A villager whispered that members of a pro-government militia "had acted without orders".</paragraph><paragraph>In Syria's war, truth has been as hard to find as peace. </paragraph><paragraph>At times, there was a massacre almost every week. In every instance, someone lives with the knowledge of what really happened. Someday, there will be a reckoning.</paragraph><paragraph>Every weapon has been deployed, no one spared: neighbourhoods wiped out, chemical weapons unleashed, even children tortured.</paragraph><image id="88735726"/><crosshead>Starvation tactics</crosshead><paragraph>One of the most powerful weapons in this war has been its simplest: food.</paragraph><paragraph>All sides have cut off food, water, medicine in their quest for power. </paragraph><paragraph>Thirteen-year-old Kifah <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35789830 --><link><caption>tried to put on a brave face</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-26333533"/></link> when we met him in the besieged Palestinian camp of Yarmouk in 2014. But he soon collapsed in tears: "There was no bread." </paragraph><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="73196812">    <caption>"They are absolutely desperate; desperate for help and desperate to get out"</caption>  </video><image id="88735995"/><paragraph>One UN official said he has had to work hard to convince warring parties that wheat flour isn't used to make bombs. </paragraph><paragraph>But, in the words of a senior US official, President Obama has been "pathologically opposed to greater military involvement in Syria". </paragraph><paragraph>Without America firmly at the helm, Arab states and Turkey have backed different groups for different goals. In contrast, President Assad has had the most loyal of friends, including Russia, Iran and Lebanon's Hezbollah.</paragraph><image id="88735991"/><paragraph>In the immediate wake of a strategic victory in the town of Qusayr in 2013, Hezbollah forces didn't hide their presence or pride. "How difficult were the battles," I asked some of the Lebanese fighters. "Easy-peasy lemon squeezy" one man replied with a grin.</paragraph><paragraph><bold>Return to Deraa</bold></paragraph><paragraph>Five years on, there is a <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35789831 --><link><caption>rare, if fragile, truce</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35748331"/></link>, only because outside players finally decided to give peace a bit of a chance. </paragraph><paragraph>This month we went back to the city of Deraa, an unassuming agricultural area thrust into the headlines of history, to find a city drained by war.</paragraph><paragraph>The unprecedented protests of 2011 had morphed into the most significant assault by rebel forces known as the Southern Front to take the city last summer.</paragraph><paragraph>Governor Mohammad Khaled al-Hannus, whom we first met in 2011, showed us floors and windows gutted and shattered by rockets.</paragraph><paragraph>"We may have made some small mistakes," he admitted, but insisted the blame belonged firmly on the other side. "Their false revolution destroyed and divided our country."</paragraph><image id="88736094"/><paragraph>We reached by telephone a teacher named Zahra in rebel-held Deraa. "A lot was destroyed, but the revolution was inevitable," she told me. "So many fled because one man wants to stay in power."</paragraph><paragraph>Defiance and distrust are undiminished. </paragraph><paragraph>Syria is a different country now. Millions fled with their children to try to begin a new life elsewhere. </paragraph><paragraph>But Syria isn't lost - yet. </paragraph><paragraph>Somewhere in between a regime and a revolution a new Syria, with remnants of its old self, could still emerge from these ruins -  but only if this war stops stealing its future. </paragraph></body>

/news/world-africa-35810599.title: BBC News - Nigeria's NNPC 'failed to pay' $16bn in oil revenues
/news/world-africa-35810599.summary: Nigeria's state-owned oil company failed to pay revenues worth $16bn (£11bn) to the government in a suspected fraud, according to an official audit.
/news/world-africa-35810599.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/72428717-5fba-1c4c-8015-4c4569206ef2"><image id="88566271"/><paragraph role="introduction">Nigeria's state-owned oil company has failed to pay the government $16bn (£11bn) in a suspected fraud, according to an official audit.</paragraph><paragraph>The Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC) provided no explanation for the missing funds, the auditor general told MPs. </paragraph><paragraph>Oil revenue accounts for two-thirds of the government's funding.</paragraph><paragraph>President Muhammadu Buhari has promised to crack down on corruption since coming to office last May.</paragraph>  <list type="unordered">    <listItem><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35810602 --><link><caption>More on this and other African news stories</caption><altText>link to bbc live page </altText><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/world-africa-35809778"/></link></listItem>    <listItem><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35810603 --><link><caption>Can Nigeria defeat oil corruption</caption><altText>link to bbc article </altText><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-34580862"/></link></listItem>    <listItem><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35785426 --><itemMeta overtyped-headline="Nigeria battles economic slowdown"><url href="/news/world-africa-35785426" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/1041d7a3-86b1-e045-a673-15364db63d58"/><assetTypeCode xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/1041d7a3-86b1-e045-a673-15364db63d58">STY</assetTypeCode><assetId xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/1041d7a3-86b1-e045-a673-15364db63d58">35785426</assetId><headline xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/b2e540bd-6442-2a4b-b325-a8bbd1b83b63">Can Nigeria breathe new life into its factories?</headline><shortHeadline xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/b2e540bd-6442-2a4b-b325-a8bbd1b83b63">Can Nigeria breathe new life into its factories?</shortHeadline><summary xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/b2e540bd-6442-2a4b-b325-a8bbd1b83b63">Nigeria, haunted by high unemployment and a sinking oil-dependent economy, is pushing to diversify its economy with a "made in Nigeria" manufacturing campaign. The BBC's Martin Patience went to the northern city of Kano to see what difference it will make.</summary><section id="99121" name="Africa" uri="/news/world/africa" url-identifier="/news/world/africa" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/1041d7a3-86b1-e045-a673-15364db63d58"/><title xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/1041d7a3-86b1-e045-a673-15364db63d58">BBC News - Can Nigeria breathe new life into its factories?</title><firstCreated xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/1041d7a3-86b1-e045-a673-15364db63d58">2016-03-11T11:32:50+00:00</firstCreated><firstPublished xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/1041d7a3-86b1-e045-a673-15364db63d58">2016-03-14T00:53:26+00:00</firstPublished><lastUpdated xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/1041d7a3-86b1-e045-a673-15364db63d58">2016-03-14T00:53:26+00:00</lastUpdated><lastPublished xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/1041d7a3-86b1-e045-a673-15364db63d58">2016-03-15T11:40:26+00:00</lastPublished><changeQueueId xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/1041d7a3-86b1-e045-a673-15364db63d58">272095012</changeQueueId><changeQueueTimestamp xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/1041d7a3-86b1-e045-a673-15364db63d58">2016-03-15T11:40:13+00:00</changeQueueTimestamp><publicationStatus xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/1041d7a3-86b1-e045-a673-15364db63d58">PUBLISHED</publicationStatus><language xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/1041d7a3-86b1-e045-a673-15364db63d58">en-gb</language><site id="825" code="news-v6" name="BBC News" front-page-uri="/news/front_page" url-identifier="/news" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/1041d7a3-86b1-e045-a673-15364db63d58"/><provider xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/1041d7a3-86b1-e045-a673-15364db63d58">cps</provider><workerCallingCard xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/1041d7a3-86b1-e045-a673-15364db63d58">app134.back.live.telhc.local-59</workerCallingCard><hasShortForm xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/1041d7a3-86b1-e045-a673-15364db63d58">false</hasShortForm></itemMeta></listItem>  </list><paragraph>The NNPC has not commented on the auditor general's findings. </paragraph><paragraph>The state oil giant has been mired in corruption allegations and losing money for many years.</paragraph><paragraph>Last month, the government announced that the NNPC would be broken up into seven different companies.</paragraph><image id="85847146"/><paragraph>Nigeria's former central bank governor Lamido Sanusi, now the Emir of Kano, was dismissed by the previous administration after saying that $20bn (£12bn) in oil revenue had gone missing in 2013.</paragraph><paragraph>A separate audit ordered under former President Goodluck Jonathan and carried out by global accountancy firm PwC, found that the NNPC had failed to pay the government $1.48bn between January 2012 and July 2013.</paragraph><paragraph>It did not provide a total figure for how much revenue the NNPC should legally have handed over to the treasury. </paragraph><paragraph>However, the company said that it could not vouch for the integrity of the information it was given when it conducted the audit. </paragraph><paragraph>Nigeria is Africa's biggest oil producer, but the economy has suffered because of the fall in the price of oil.</paragraph></body>
/news/world-africa-35810599.shortFormBody: <shortFormBody xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/72428717-5fba-1c4c-8015-4c4569206ef2"><paragraph>Nigeria's state-owned oil company has failed to pay the government $16bn (£11bn) in a suspected fraud, according to an official audit.</paragraph><paragraph>The Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC) provided no explanation for the missing funds, the auditor general told MPs.</paragraph><paragraph>Oil revenue accounts for two-thirds of the government's funding.</paragraph><paragraph>President Muhammadu Buhari has promised to crack down on corruption since coming to office last May.</paragraph></shortFormBody>

items.shortHeadline: Can Nigeria breathe new life into its factories?
items.summary: Nigeria, haunted by high unemployment and a sinking oil-dependent economy, is pushing to diversify its economy with a "made in Nigeria" manufacturing campaign. The BBC's Martin Patience went to the northern city of Kano to see what difference it will make.
items.title: BBC News - Can Nigeria breathe new life into its factories?

/news/world-europe-35807961.title: BBC News - Breivik gives Nazi salute in court return to challenge jail isolation
/news/world-europe-35807961.summary: Jailed Norwegian mass murderer Anders Behring Breivik gives a Nazi salute as he returns to court to argue that his isolation violates his rights.
/news/world-europe-35807961.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/78671f30-d0d0-ef4b-936f-9545b11fd993"><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="88774939">    <caption>Anders Breivik gave a Nazi salute in court</caption>  </video><paragraph role="introduction">Jailed Norwegian mass murderer Anders Behring Breivik has given a Nazi salute upon returning to court to argue that his isolation violates his rights.</paragraph><paragraph>The right-wing extremist says he is being held in inhuman conditions but the state rejects this.</paragraph><paragraph>Breivik killed 77 people in 2011 when he bombed central Oslo before going on a shooting spree at a Labour Youth camp on the island of Utoeya.</paragraph><paragraph>He was sentenced to 21 years in prison in 2012.</paragraph><paragraph>Tuesday's hearing, in a prison gym converted into a court, marks his first public appearance since then.</paragraph><paragraph>He entered the court in a grey suit shortly before 09:00 (08:00 GMT). He shook hands with his lawyers and made the Nazi salute after police removed his handcuffs. </paragraph><paragraph>Breivik, 37, is mainly challenging the government over his solitary confinement, as well as over general conditions including what he claims is the excessive use of handcuffs.</paragraph><image id="88775097"/><paragraph>In his opening statement, Breivik's lawyer Oystein Storrvik said his client's punishment was worse than the death penalty, which is outlawed in Norway.</paragraph><paragraph>Breivik accuses the Norwegian government of breaching two clauses of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR).</paragraph><paragraph>One of the clauses guarantees the right to respect for "private and family life" and "correspondence", while the other prohibits "inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment".</paragraph><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="88779215">    <caption>Mads Andenas, whose niece survived Brievik's attack, said his appeal was "something we have to go through"</caption>  </video><paragraph>In court, Mr Storrvik cited an earlier case involving the French government and Ilich Ramirez Sanchez, an imprisoned Venezuelan left-wing militant better known as "Carlos the Jackal".</paragraph><paragraph>In that case, the European Court of Human Rights ruled in favour of arguments that solitary confinement had violated some of the prisoner's rights. Mr Storrvik argued that Ramirez Sanchez had nonetheless been held in better conditions than Breivik.</paragraph><paragraph>Breivik is the only prisoner in the high-security wing of Skien prison, about 100km (60 miles) south-west of the capital Oslo.  Authorities say Breivik's correspondence is censored to stop him setting up an "extremist network". </paragraph><paragraph>His visits are almost all with professionals across a glass partition. According to his lawyer, Breivik's mother was the only person allowed to visit him without being separated by the glass screen. </paragraph><paragraph>The attorney general's office has insisted that Breivik's prison conditions are "well within the limits of what is permitted" under the convention.</paragraph><paragraph>The court hearing is expected to run until Friday. Breivik is expected to testify on Wednesday.</paragraph><paragraph>If the court decides that Breivik's prison conditions are so strict that they cause him harm and violate his human rights, it could order an easing of restrictions.</paragraph><image id="88773972"/><paragraph>Last September, Breivik threatened to <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35810884 --><link><caption>starve himself to death</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-34401166"/></link> in protest at his treatment in prison.</paragraph><paragraph>His cell at Skien prison has a TV and computer but he has no access to the internet.</paragraph><paragraph>In a letter to media outlets in Norway and Sweden, he said he was kept in almost total isolation, with time outside his cell limited to one hour a day.</paragraph><paragraph>He said the harsh prison conditions had forced him to drop out of a <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35810885 --><link><caption>political science course at the University of Oslo</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-33571929"/></link>.</paragraph><paragraph>Breivik was first held at Ila Detention and Security Prison near Oslo before being moved to Skien in 2013. At Ila, he also complained <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35810886 --><link><caption>of being held in "inhumane" conditions</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-20270325"/></link>.</paragraph><paragraph>In a letter to prison authorities, he said his cell was poorly decorated and had no view. He also complained that his coffee was served cold, he did not have enough butter for his bread, and he was not allowed moisturiser.</paragraph></body>
/news/world-europe-35807961.shortFormBody: <shortFormBody xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/78671f30-d0d0-ef4b-936f-9545b11fd993"><paragraph>Jailed Norwegian mass murderer Anders Behring Breivik has given a Nazi salute upon returning to court to argue that his isolation violates his rights.</paragraph><paragraph>The right-wing extremist says he is being held in inhuman conditions but the state rejects this.</paragraph><paragraph>Breivik killed 77 people in 2011 when he bombed central Oslo before going on a shooting spree at a Labour Youth camp on the island of Utoeya.</paragraph><paragraph>He was sentenced to 21 years in prison in 2012.</paragraph></shortFormBody>

/news/world-europe-35810193.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/70b135ee-3fd9-c449-b775-6e1c5ac2c25f"><paragraph>Norwegian mass murderer Anders Behring Breivik has given a Nazi salute upon his return to court to accuse the government of violating his human rights by holding him in isolation.</paragraph><paragraph>The mass murderer killed 77 people in 2011 when he bombed central Oslo and shot many of the people at a youth camp on the island of Utoya.</paragraph></body>

/news/world-europe-35810196.title: BBC News - Anders Breivik: Human rights not just for 'nice people'
/news/world-europe-35810196.summary: A Norwegian law professor, whose niece was on Utoeya island when Brievik opened fire, says the mass murderer's appeal process is something "we have to go through".
/news/world-europe-35810196.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/7eef9958-b54b-d74d-93d4-eb4b9f72771c"><paragraph>A Norwegian law professor, whose niece was on Utoeya island when Anders Brievik opened fire, says the killer's appeal process is something "we have to go through".</paragraph><paragraph>One of Mads Andenas's students was murdered on the island.</paragraph><paragraph>However he thinks it is important the appeal is heard as "human rights are not only for people who are nice".</paragraph></body>

/news/world-europe-14276074.title: BBC News - Norway attacks: The victims
/news/world-europe-14276074.summary: Full list of the victims of the twin terror attacks on Norway that have been confirmed by police, family or government sources.
/news/world-europe-14276074.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/b5c53249-6ae3-e059-e040-850a02846523"><paragraph role="introduction"><bold>Seventy seven people were killed in the bombing and massacre carried out by Anders Behring Breivik on 22 July 2011.  Many of those killed on the island of Utoeya were involved with the Norwegian Labour Party's youth wing, the AUF.</bold></paragraph><image id="83068124"/><crosshead>Oslo bombing</crosshead><image id="88775358"/><paragraph><bold>Hanna Endresen</bold>, 61, Oslo</paragraph><paragraph>Receptionist in the security department of the Government Administration Services. She was described as a "good colleague". </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Tove Ashill Knutsen</bold>, 56, Oslo</paragraph><paragraph>Secretary with the electricians and information technology workers' union. On her way to subway station when bomb exploded. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Kai Hauge</bold>, 32, Oslo</paragraph><paragraph>Owned a bar and restaurant in Oslo. A colleague described his death as "a great loss".  </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Jon Vegard Lervag,</bold> 32, Oslo</paragraph><paragraph>A lawyer who worked in the justice department. He was described as "socially engaged". </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Ida Marie Hill,</bold> 34, Oslo</paragraph><paragraph>Originally from Grue, Hedmark county, Ida worked as an adviser to the ministry of justice. She was described as "a dear and highly-valued employee".</paragraph><paragraph><bold>Hanne Ekroll Loevlie,</bold> 30, Oslo </paragraph><paragraph>A senior government worker originally from Tyristrand, Buskerud county. Colleagues said she "represented the best in us". </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Anne Lise Holter,</bold> 51, Valer i Oestfold, Oestfold county </paragraph><paragraph>Senior consultant to Norway's PM Jens Stoltenberg's office. Officials sent their "warmest thoughts and sympathy" to her family and friends.   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Kjersti Berg Sand,</bold> 26, Nord-Ordal </paragraph><paragraph>Worked on international issues in Justice Department. Colleagues said they had lost a "dear and highly valued employee". </paragraph><image id="83068124"/><crosshead>Utoeya island shooting </crosshead><image id="88775359"/><paragraph><bold>Mona Abdinur,</bold> 18, Oslo </paragraph><paragraph>The committed young politician was described as "a well-loved friend, who was socially engaged and interested in multicultural issues".   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Maria Maageroe Johannesen</bold>, 17, Noetteroey, Vestfold county </paragraph><paragraph>Student at Greve Forest High School who was interested in music, dance and drama. Described as a wonderful, conscientious girl who was a "ray of sunshine". </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Ismail Haji Ahmed</bold> 19 Hamar, Hedmark county </paragraph><paragraph>Better known as Isma Brown after appearing on a talent show. The dance instructor was described as  a "very bubbly, happy, caring and happy boy. He was very positive with a very big heart."</paragraph><paragraph><bold>Ronja Soettar Johansen,</bold> 17, Vefsn, Nordland county </paragraph><paragraph>An active blogger, Ronja had a keen interest in music. Friends said she was "a person with courage, commitment and kindness". </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Thomas Margido Antonsen,</bold> 16, Oslo </paragraph><paragraph>A student council representative. Described by friends as "a boy who spread joy".</paragraph><paragraph><bold>Sondre Kjoeren,</bold> 17, Orkdal, Soer-Troendelag county </paragraph><paragraph>Described as a gentle but committed person. He was said to have been heavily involved in efforts to get a new sports hall in his village.  </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Porntip Ardam,</bold> 21, Oslo </paragraph><paragraph>Known as Pamela. She was described as talented, super-intelligent, politically active and down to earth.</paragraph><paragraph><bold>Margrethe Boeyum Kloeven,</bold> 16, Baerum, Akershus county </paragraph><paragraph>The student council leader was described as an "active and versatile girl". </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Modupe Ellen Awoyemi,</bold> 15, Drammen, Buskerud county </paragraph><paragraph>Daughter of the city council politician Lola Awoyemi. Described as a kind and open girl, who was active in AUF discussions.   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Syvert Knudsen,</bold> 17, Lyngdal, Vest-Agder county </paragraph><paragraph>The student politician is believed to have been one of the first shot on the island. His family described him as a "bubbly" boy with a keen interest in music. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Lene Maria Bergum,</bold> 19, Namsos, Nord-Troendelag </paragraph><paragraph>Her head teacher described her as an excellent, beautiful youth, who was sociable, interested in international issues. She had planned to start a summer job as a journalist.</paragraph><paragraph><bold>Anders Kristiansen,</bold> 18, Bardu, Troms county </paragraph><paragraph>An active young politician and leader of the AUF in his area. He was said to be "full of initiative" with "a great desire to work in politics". </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Kevin Daae Berland,</bold> 15, Akoey, Hordaland county </paragraph><paragraph>Active in Askoey AUF and was involved in local politics as well as being a member of the youth council.</paragraph><paragraph><bold>Elisabeth Troennes Lie,</bold> 16, Halden, Oestfold county </paragraph><paragraph>A board member of the Halden AUF. Described as "the sweetest person in the world". </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Trond Berntsen,</bold> 51, Oevre Eiker, Buskerud county </paragraph><paragraph>Crown Princess of Norway's step-brother. The royal court said the off-duty police officer was killed while working as a security guard on the island.   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Gunnar Linaker,</bold> 23, Bardu, Troms county </paragraph><paragraph>Regional secretary of Labour party's youth wing. Father described him as a "calm, big teddy bear with lots of humour and lots of love". </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Sverre Flate Bjoerkavag,</bold> 28, Sula, Soer-Troendelag county </paragraph><paragraph>Union official concerned about justice, equality and community thinking. Described as a well-liked young man who fought for pupils and students' rights. Was training to be a nurse. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Tamta Lipartelliani,</bold> 23, Georgia </paragraph><paragraph>Secretary of the international committee of the Young Socialists of Georgia. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Torjus Jakobsen Blattmann,</bold> 17, Kristiansand,Vest-Agder county </paragraph><paragraph>Son of former political adviser. His father said he was a boy "full of humour" who loved playing the guitar.</paragraph><paragraph><bold>Eva Kathinka Lutken,</bold> 17, Sarpsborg, Oestfold county </paragraph><paragraph>She was described as an active politician who was well liked. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Monica Boesei,</bold> 45, Hole, Buskerud county </paragraph><paragraph>PM Jens Stoltenberg  said: "To many of us, she was the embodiment of Utoeya. And now she is dead. Shot and killed whilst taking care of and giving joy to young people."</paragraph><paragraph><bold>Even Flugstad Malmedal,</bold> 18, Gjoevik, Oppland county </paragraph><paragraph>The student with an interest in politics was described as "a gentle boy who stood up for his friends". </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Carina Borgund,</bold> 18, Oslo </paragraph><paragraph>Friends and family said she was "kind, caring, gentle and positive. She loved life and spread joy to everyone around her".   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Tarald Kuven Mjelde,</bold> 18, Osteroey </paragraph><paragraph>Said to be a big fan of  Chelsea football team and described as "very warm, friendly and socially engaged". </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Johannes Buoe,</bold> 14, Mandal, Vest-Agder county </paragraph><paragraph>"An independent boy with a good sense of humour," his parents told NRK. He was interested in dogs, hunting, snowmobiling and took an active part in the youth community.   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Ruth Benedicte Vatndal Nilsen,</bold> 15, Toensberg, Vestfold county</paragraph><paragraph>Described by friends as "always happy, positive, and without prejudice". </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Asta Sofie Helland Dahl,</bold> 16, Sortland, Nordland county </paragraph><paragraph>Teachers described her as a wonderful girl who was "open and cheerful".    </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Hakon Oedegaard,</bold> 17, Trondheim, Soer-Troendelag county </paragraph><paragraph>Music student at Heimdal high school and member of Byasen school marching band. Described as a role model for others in the band. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Sondre Furseth Dale,</bold> 17, Haugesund, Rogaland county </paragraph><paragraph>Had large network of friends through music scene and politics. Described as a dedicated person who put 100% into everything he was interested in.   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Emil Okkenhaug,</bold> 15, Levanger, Nord-Troendelag county  </paragraph><paragraph>A sports lover described as modest and liked by all who knew him. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Monica Iselin Didriksen,</bold> 18, Sund, Hordaland county </paragraph><paragraph>Active in Sund AUF, she was described by friends as a unique and bubbly girl. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Diderik Aamodt Olsen,</bold> 19, Nesodden, Akershus county </paragraph><paragraph>Vice president of Nesodden AUF. He was the youngest member of editorial staff working on the organisation's magazine. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Gizem Dogan,</bold> 17, Trondheim, Soer-Troendelag county </paragraph><paragraph>Described as a clever student who contributed to the cohesion of her class. Elected as central member of local AUF a month before the tragedy.   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Henrik Pedersen,</bold> 27, Porsanger, Finnmark county </paragraph><paragraph>Leader of Porsanger AUF. Described as a "breath of fresh air" in the local community. A Labour colleague said he was very engaged and engaging. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Andreas Edvardsen,</bold>  18, Sarpsborg, Oestfold county </paragraph><paragraph>Director of Sarpsborg AUF and active in in the Labour youth league regional committee in Oestfold. Described as "a very caring and confident person".    </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Rolf Christopher Johansen Perreau,</bold> 25, Trondheim, Soer-Troendelag county </paragraph><paragraph>Known as Christopher. Long-term member of the AUF and was elected to the board in October. Described as a skilled orator and a charismatic young politician. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Tore Eikeland</bold> ,21, Osteroy, Hordaland county </paragraph><paragraph>PM Jens Stoltenberg described him as "one of our most talented young politicians".   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Karar Mustafa Qasim,</bold>  19, Vestby, Akershus county </paragraph><paragraph>Originally from Iraq, Karar was with friends at summer camp when he was killed. The local mayor described his death as "an enormous tragedy".  </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Bendik Rosnaes Ellingsen,</bold> 18, Rygge, Oestfold county </paragraph><paragraph>Had a summer job at the justice ministry before attending camp. He was secretary of Moss Regional Labour Youth, who said they had lost a caring, open and inclusive boy.   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Bano Abobakar Rashid,</bold> 18, Nesodden, Akershus county </paragraph><paragraph>Leader of Nesodden AUF. She was said to have dedicated her life to fighting for democracy and against racism. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Aleksander Aas Eriksen,</bold> 16, Meråker, Nord-Troendelag county</paragraph><paragraph>Described as socially-engaged as well as "impulsive and passionate".    </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Henrik Rasmussen,</bold> 18, Hadsel, Nordland county </paragraph><paragraph>Treasurer of Hadsel AUF. Said to be a very committed person, both in politics and culture.  </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Andrine Bakkene Espeland,</bold> 16, Fredrikstad, Oestfold county </paragraph><paragraph>Described as a politically-engaged girl who was keen to take care of the weakest.   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Synne Roeyneland,</bold> 18, Oslo </paragraph><paragraph>A student described by friends as a "funny girl, who always had something to offer: opinions about politics and love and fun and witty comments". </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Hanne Balch Fjalestad,</bold> 43, Lunner, Oppland county </paragraph><paragraph>Danish government confirmed the Danish national was killed while working on the island as a first aid assistant. She was with her 20-year-old daughter, who survived the shooting.   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Ida Beathe Rogne,</bold> 17, Oestre Toten, Oppland county </paragraph><paragraph>A keen student described as happy and funny as well as determined. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Silje Merete Fjellbu,</bold> 17, Tinn, Telemark county </paragraph><paragraph>Student politician described as a "wonderful girl who had much to contribute".   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Simon Saebo,</bold> 18, Salangen, Troms county </paragraph><paragraph>The student politician was said to be a natural leader. Those who knew him described him as trusting and kind, and a person who showed great concern for others. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Hanne Kristine Fridtun,</bold> 19 Stryn, Sogn og Fjordane county </paragraph><paragraph>The nursing student was the local AUF county chairman. Described as energetic with great commitment.   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Marianne Sandvik,</bold> 16, Hundvag, Stavanger </paragraph><paragraph>The student was described as a quiet girl who always stood up for those who needed her. Her father said she was concerned with injustice in the world. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Andreas Dalby Groennesby,</bold> 17, Stange, Hedmark county </paragraph><paragraph>His father had exchanged text messages with him before the shooting. His father told NRK that public support had helped at a painful, terrible time.   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Fredrik Lund Schjetne,</bold> 18, Eidsvoll, Akershus county </paragraph><paragraph>Described by friends as "a great person" whom it was   "an honour" to have known. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Snorre Haller,</bold> 30, Trondheim, Soer-Troendelag county </paragraph><paragraph>Painter and union man. He was a board member of the Joint Association's Central Youth Committee. Described as a "kind, quiet and generous man".   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Lejla Selaci,</bold> 17, Fredrikstad, Oestfold county </paragraph><paragraph>Leader of the AUF in Fredrikstad. Described as a "very happy and social girl who committed herself to what she believed in".  </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Rune Havdal,</bold> 43, Oevre Eiker, Buskerud county </paragraph><paragraph>Worked as a security guard on the island of Utoeya.   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Birgitte Smetbak,</bold> 15, Noetteroey, Vestfold county </paragraph><paragraph>Politicians from her local area said hearing news of her death was "a difficult day". </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Guro Vartdal Havoll,</bold> 18, Oersta, Moere og Romsdal </paragraph><paragraph>An active and determined politician, the young student's family said she was inspired by Ghandi and wanted to make the world a "better place".   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Isabel Victoria Green Sogn,</bold> 17, Oslo </paragraph><paragraph>An enthusiastic member of the AUF who saw her future involved in politics. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Ingrid Berg Heggelund,</bold> 18, As, Akershus county </paragraph><paragraph>A student who said she  loved going to school.   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Silje Stamneshagen,</bold> 18, Askoey, Hordaland county </paragraph><paragraph>Active in Askoey AUF and played in school band. Classmates described her as a happy girl who lit up the school day and every day. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Karin Elena Holst,</bold> 15, Rana, Nordland county  </paragraph><paragraph>A member of the Rana AUF, she spoke to her mother during the shooting. She had urged her daughter to hang up and hide.   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Victoria Stenberg,</bold> 17, Nes, Akershus county </paragraph><paragraph>The oldest of three siblings, she was said to be looking forward to the youth camp.  </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Eivind Hovden,</bold> 15, Tokke, Telemark county </paragraph><paragraph>Eivind was involved in his local youth centre and was attending his first summer camp. Described as an "amazing guy, always happy, caring and helpful".   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Tina Sukuvara,</bold> 18, Vadsoe, Finnmark county  </paragraph><paragraph>Described as "very talented and engaged" and a person who participated actively in political debates.  </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Jamil Rafal Mohamad Jamil,</bold> 20, Eigersund, Rogaland county  </paragraph><paragraph>Originally from Iraq, Jamil was described as happy, attentive and curious with a strong desire to contribute.     </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Sharidyn Svebakk-Boehn,</bold> 14, Drammen, Buskerud county </paragraph><paragraph>Known as Sissi to friends and family, the schoolgirl was described as a "beautiful, caring and vibrant girl". </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Steinar Jessen,</bold> 16 Alta, Finnmark county </paragraph><paragraph>A keen member of the AUF. The mayor of Alta described him as "a flower that would have grown big and strong".   </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Havard Vederhus,</bold> 21, Oslo </paragraph><paragraph>Elected leader of Oslo Labour Youth in February. Friends said he was  "ambitious and fearless". </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Espen Joergensen,</bold> 17, Bodoe, Nordland county </paragraph><paragraph>Had recently become head of Bodoe AUF. His best friend said he was someone who could "light up the darkest days".     </paragraph><paragraph><italic>Source: Oslo police, Norwegian government, NRK  </italic></paragraph></body>

/news/world-europe-33571929.title: BBC News - Anders Breivik accepted at Norway's University of Oslo
/news/world-europe-33571929.summary: Norwegian mass murderer Anders Behring Breivik wins place to study political science at Oslo University.
/news/world-europe-33571929.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/587dd688-4260-0b4b-9ea2-bae6db049ab5"><image id="84340217"/><paragraph role="introduction">Norwegian mass killer Anders Behring Breivik has won a place to study political science at Oslo's university.</paragraph><paragraph>The 36 year old admitted killing 77 people when he bombed central Oslo and then went on a shooting spree at a youth camp on a nearby island in 2011.</paragraph><paragraph>Breivik has been studying certain course modules since first applying to the University of Oslo in 2013, but he will now be taught as a full student.</paragraph><paragraph>He will have no contact with staff or students as he studies from his cell.</paragraph><paragraph>In 2012, he was sentenced to the maximum 21 years in prison for carrying out Norway's worst massacre since World War Two.</paragraph><paragraph>This jail term can be extended if he is deemed to remain a danger to society.</paragraph><paragraph>The university's rector, Ole Petter Ottersen, said that Norwegian inmates "have a right to pursue higher education in Norway if they meet the admission requirements and are successful in competition with other applicants."</paragraph><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 33571934 --><link><caption>Writing on the university's website</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://blogg.uio.no/unidir/ottersen/content/anders-behring-breivik-is-offered-admission-to-the-university-of-oslo"/></link>, Mr Ottersen admitted that the university had faced "moral dilemmas" about Breivik's admission.</paragraph><paragraph>The rector added that the university had students whose family members had been killed by Breivik. However, he said that the university would abide by its rules "for our own sake, not for his."</paragraph><paragraph>As he studies from his prison, Breivik will be subject to strict regulations. He will be allowed no access to internet resources or receive any personal guidance from tutors. All communication with the university will take place via "a contact person in prison".</paragraph><image id="84341826"/><paragraph>Breivik first applied to study in 2013 but did not meet entry requirements as he had never completed secondary school. Instead, he was allowed to study certain political science modules. </paragraph><paragraph>His deadly rampage at a Labour Party youth camp on Utoeya island was found by an <!-- CPS Asset ID: 33571930 --><link><caption>Oslo court to have been a premeditated act of terrorism.</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-19365616"/></link></paragraph><paragraph>He harboured extremist right-wing views and claimed he had reacted against what he saw as a Marxist-Islamic takeover of Europe.</paragraph></body>
/news/world-europe-33571929.shortFormBody: <shortFormBody xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/587dd688-4260-0b4b-9ea2-bae6db049ab5"><paragraph>Norwegian mass killer Anders Behring Breivik has won a place to study political science at Oslo's university.</paragraph><paragraph>The 36 year old admitted killing 77 people when he bombed central Oslo and then went on a shooting spree at a youth camp on a nearby island in 2011.</paragraph><paragraph>Breivik has been studying certain course modules since first applying to the University of Oslo in 2013, but he will now be taught as a full student.</paragraph><paragraph>He will have no contact with staff or students as he studies from his cell.</paragraph></shortFormBody>

/news/election-us-2016-35810887.title: BBC News - US presidential election: Five states vote in primaries
/news/election-us-2016-35810887.summary: Five US states hold primaries for November's presidential election, giving Democrat and Republican front-runners a chance to cement their leads.
/news/election-us-2016-35810887.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/28cf7440-a616-6346-90d9-c851809ee4f3"><image id="88780273"/><paragraph role="introduction">Five US states are holding primaries for November's presidential election, in a crucial round that could give Democrat and Republican front-runners a chance to cement their leads.</paragraph><paragraph>Polls have opened in Ohio and Florida - both deemed key states - as well as in North Carolina, Illinois and Missouri.</paragraph><paragraph>Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton will hope to fend off a challenge from her resurgent rival, Bernie Sanders.</paragraph><paragraph>Meanwhile Donald Trump will aim to edge out his Republican rivals in the race.</paragraph><paragraph>The New York real estate mogul is the favourite to win his party's nomination but has run into fierce opposition from within the Republican establishment, as well as facing condemnation from the Democrats.</paragraph><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35814408 --><link><caption>Live updates on crucial votes</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/live/election-us-2016-35404043"/></link></paragraph><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35805861 --><itemMeta overtyped-headline="What to expect from Super Tuesday - the sequel"><url href="/news/election-us-2016-35805861" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/e2d99efb-2b8f-5743-8b0f-21171ee41546"/><assetTypeCode xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/e2d99efb-2b8f-5743-8b0f-21171ee41546">CSP</assetTypeCode><assetId xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/e2d99efb-2b8f-5743-8b0f-21171ee41546">35805861</assetId><headline xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/b2eefb16-62f5-0b4f-b2f1-3f86d30936ab">US election 2016: What to expect from Super Tuesday - the sequel</headline><shortHeadline xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/b2eefb16-62f5-0b4f-b2f1-3f86d30936ab">What to expect from Super Tuesday - the sequel</shortHeadline><summary xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/b2eefb16-62f5-0b4f-b2f1-3f86d30936ab">The original Super Tuesday primary voting put Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump securely in the lead. The Super Tuesday sequel this week could seal the deal.</summary><section id="102423" name="US Election 2016" uri="/news/election/us2016" url-identifier="/news/election/us2016" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/812d0251-d6b4-2d47-ad47-f73117cc3eec"/><provider xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/812d0251-d6b4-2d47-ad47-f73117cc3eec">cps</provider><workerCallingCard xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/812d0251-d6b4-2d47-ad47-f73117cc3eec">app135.back.live.telhc.local-60</workerCallingCard><hasShortForm xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset/812d0251-d6b4-2d47-ad47-f73117cc3eec">false</hasShortForm></itemMeta></paragraph><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35814253 --><link><caption>What Trump says about protesters at his rallies</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/election-us-2016-35793103"/></link></paragraph><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35814254 --><link><caption>Why are Americans so angry?</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-35406324"/></link></paragraph><paragraph>Mr Sanders, a Vermont senator, and Mrs Clinton, a former Secretary of State, have accused Mr Trump of encouraging his supporters to beat up protesters, after violence broke out at a planned appearance by Mr Trump in Chicago.</paragraph><paragraph>Meanwhile, Republican candidate Marco Rubio, currently in third place, has said he must win in his home state of Florida in order to stop Mr Trump from "hijacking" his party's nomination.</paragraph><paragraph>Ohio Governor John Kasich is also aiming for a win in his home state in order to obstruct Mr Trump's progress to the nomination.</paragraph><paragraph>Victories for any of Mr Trump's rivals - Mr Rubio, Mr Kasich, or Senator Ted Cruz of Texas - would give hope to the Republicans fighting to block him.</paragraph><include>  <title>Delegate tracker</title>  <path platform="highweb" href="/news/special/2016/newsspec_13489/content/index.inc?responsive=true&app-clickable=true&app-image=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.files.bbci.co.uk%2Fvj%2Flive%2Fidt-images%2Fapp-image-delegate-tracker%2Fsuper_tuesday_app_promo_g4y8z.png"/>  </include><image id="88781748"/></body>
/news/election-us-2016-35810887.shortFormBody: <shortFormBody xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/28cf7440-a616-6346-90d9-c851809ee4f3"><paragraph>Five US states are holding primaries for November's presidential election, in a crucial round that could give Democrat and Republican front-runners a chance to cement their leads.</paragraph><paragraph>Polls have opened in Ohio and Florida - both deemed key states - as well as in North Carolina, Illinois and Missouri.</paragraph><paragraph>Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton will hope to fend off a challenge from her resurgent rival, Bernie Sanders.</paragraph><paragraph>Meanwhile Donald Trump will aim to edge out his Republican rivals in the race.</paragraph></shortFormBody>

/news/live/election-us-2016-35404043.title: BBC News - US election 2016: Candidates battle to win key races in Ohio and Florida
/news/live/election-us-2016-35404043.summary: Democrat Hillary Clinton and Republican Donald Trump battle to strengthen their respective leads in large, winner-take-all states.
keyPoints: Florida, Ohio, Illinois, Missouri and North Carolina are holding primaries on 15 March, dubbed Super Tuesday II
The Northern Mariana Islands are also holding a Republican caucus. In total, more than 1,000 delegates are up for grabs today
Republican front-runner Donald Trump leads most contests including delegate-rich Florida, with second-placed Ted Cruz hoping to improve his count
Ohio Governor John Kasich and Florida Senator Marco Rubio face big tests in their home states and hope wins will keep them in the Republican race
Democrat Hillary Clinton hopes to build on her lead - she has 774 delegates so far, while Bernie Sanders has 553
The Vermont Senator is looking to repeat his surprise win in Michigan in similar states like Illinois and Ohio
