/news/election-us-2016-35805861.title: BBC News - US election 2016: What to expect from Super Tuesday - the sequel
/news/election-us-2016-35805861.summary: The original Super Tuesday primary voting put Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump securely in the lead. The Super Tuesday sequel this week could seal the deal.
/news/election-us-2016-35805861.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/b2eefb16-62f5-0b4f-b2f1-3f86d30936ab"><image id="88770362"/><paragraph role="introduction">The "Super Tuesday" primaries and caucuses, held on 1 March in 11 states across the US, were a political blockbuster, rocketing Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton to daunting leads for their parties' nomination.</paragraph><paragraph>Like any good blockbuster, Super Tuesday has a sequel. Super Tuesday II, which takes place this week, has fewer states in play - Florida, Ohio, Illinois, Missouri and North Carolina - but it could finish what the first Tuesday of March started. </paragraph><paragraph>By Wednesday morning Mrs Clinton and Mr Trump may have built near insurmountable leads in their nomination contests. Or the 2016 election saga could continue with countless more episodes in store.</paragraph><paragraph>Here's a quick look at everything that's at stake this week - and why.</paragraph><crosshead>Where do the two presidential nomination contests stand right now?</crosshead><paragraph>When figuring out who's winning and who's losing in the race for the presidential nominations to the two major US parties, it all comes down to who has the most delegates to the national party conventions. It's at these conventions, to be held in July, that the Republican and Democratic nominees are chosen.</paragraph><paragraph>Although the rules vary slightly, the delegates at both party conventions vote on who gets the nomination and a simple majority carries the day. For the Democrats that means 2,386 out of 4,765 delegates. For Republicans the magic number is 1,237 out of a total of 2,472.</paragraph><include>  <title>Delegate tracker</title>  <path platform="highweb" href="/news/special/2016/newsspec_13489/content/index.inc?responsive=true&app-clickable=true&app-image=http%3A%2F%2Fnews.files.bbci.co.uk%2Fvj%2Flive%2Fidt-images%2Fapp-image-delegate-tracker%2Fsuper_tuesday_app_promo_g4y8z.png"/>  </include><paragraph>As of Monday businessman Donald Trump leads the Republican race with 460 delegates, followed by Texas Senator Ted Cruz (370), Florida Senator Marco Rubio (163) and Ohio Governor John Kasich (63).</paragraph><paragraph>Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton leads the Democratic race with 774 delegates, while Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders has 553.</paragraph><crosshead>The delegate calculation for the Democrats is more complicated than that, isn't it?</crosshead><paragraph>Sigh. Yes, it is.</paragraph><paragraph>The Democratic total excludes more than 700 "superdelegates" - party functionaries and officeholders who also have a vote in the party convention. Mrs Clinton currently has a significant lead among those who have announced their endorsement, garnering the support of 465 versus only 25 who are currently backing Mr Sanders.</paragraph><image id="88770107"/><paragraph>Superdelegates are free to change their mind at any point before the convention, however, and it's unlikely they'd buck popular opinion if Mr Sanders is the choice of a majority of Democratic voters.</paragraph><paragraph>The Republicans have something similar to superdelegates at their convention but there are fewer of them and most are locked into supporting whoever their state voted for in its primary or caucus.</paragraph><crosshead>So what's so super about this Super Tuesday for Republicans?</crosshead><paragraph>For Republicans this latest slate of nomination contests is important not just because of the number of convention delegates up for grabs - 349 - but how they will be apportioned.</paragraph><paragraph>While the first Super Tuesday had a whopping 595 delegates at play, 15 March marks the first time states can hold "winner-take-all" primaries. The entire batch of delegates is awarded to the winner with even the narrowest plurality of the total state vote.</paragraph><image id="88745270"/><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35808635 --><link><caption>Will Florida be Marco Rubio's last stand?</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.com/news/election-us-2016-35703304"/></link></paragraph><paragraph>Florida (99 delegates) and Ohio (63) both use this system. Missouri (53) and Illinois (69) are winner-take-all at the congressional district level, so if one candidate performs well across the state that person could very well secure the entire bounty. Only North Carolina (69) will apportion its delegates proportionally based on the overall popular vote.</paragraph><paragraph>What all this means is that if Mr Trump, who leads in many of the state polls, does particularly well on Tuesday he could effectively lock up the nomination.</paragraph><paragraph>If, for instance, he wins both Ohio and Florida - a combined 162 delegates - he would only have to win about half of the remaining delegates over the next two months to assure a majority at the Republican convention.</paragraph><crosshead>What could stop Trump on Tuesday?</crosshead><paragraph>Mr Trump's biggest obstacle on Tuesday is that to win the two top prizes, Florida and Ohio, he will have to take down two rivals fighting on their home territory.</paragraph><paragraph>Mr Rubio, a distant third in the delegate count and coming off the multiple fourth-place finishes last week, is making a last stand in the state that sent him to the US Senate in 2010. He's spent almost the entire last two weeks campaigning across Florida in the hopes a win will jump-start his campaign.</paragraph><paragraph>According to recent polls, however, he continues to trail in the state and among the third of Florida Republicans who have already cast their ballots during the early voting period.</paragraph><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="88671039">    <caption>'Hungry Hungry' Elephants: What's a brokered convention and will Republicans have one?</caption>  </video><paragraph>Ohio looks like it will be a dogfight between Mr Trump and Mr Kasich, who as the sitting governor has a formidable campaign network in the state and remains popular among Republican voters there. Mr Kasich is a distant fourth in the total delegate count, so Ohio would provide him not only with his first outright win but also a much-needed numbers boost. </paragraph><paragraph>Mr Cruz beat Mr Trump in his home state of Texas on Super Tuesday and his second place in the delegate count seems secure regardless of this Tuesday's outcome. His goal is to try to keep pace with Mr Trump as best he can and prove he has nationwide appeal, even if he doesn't score any statewide wins.</paragraph><paragraph>The Texan is playing a long game at this point, hoping to outlast his anti-Trump rivals and then take down the New York real-estate mogul later, in a head-to-head showdown. </paragraph><paragraph>If Mr Trump loses in Florida or Ohio - or both - and if Mr Cruz or one of the other candidates does well in the other states, it could put a real dent in the New Yorker's chances of becoming the nominee without a brutal fight at the Republican convention.</paragraph><crosshead>Why is Tuesday so super for the Democrats?</crosshead><paragraph>The Democrats don't play the winner-take-all game, but that doesn't mean that this isn't a pivotal day for their presidential race as well.</paragraph><paragraph>Although Mrs Clinton has a solid delegate lead (with or without the superdelegates) Mr Sanders is riding a wave of momentum following a shocking upset in the Michigan primary last Tuesday. Polls leading up to the vote there showed him trailing by double digits, and he ended up with a narrow victory.</paragraph><paragraph>Now all eyes are on whether he can outperform polling once again, particularly in states that are near Michigan, like Ohio and Illinois, and have similar levels of white, pro-union, working-class voters who have been receptive to Mr Sanders's economic populism and anti-trade-deal rhetoric.</paragraph><image id="88770364"/><paragraph>Mrs Clinton has consistently performed well in the south, so she could post big wins in Florida and North Carolina that would ameliorate close losses in the mid-west. She's still the odds-on favourite to win the nomination, but a poor performance on Tuesday will make the road much more difficult. </paragraph><paragraph>Across-the-board losses, if they were to happen, would throw the Democratic race into total turmoil. </paragraph><crosshead>Open primaries, closed primaries - why does it matter?</crosshead><paragraph>There's one more thing to take into consideration when looking at these coming primaries. Some of them are "open" to any voters, while others are "closed" to only registered party voters.</paragraph><paragraph>That makes a difference because, at least so far, Mr Trump and Mr Sanders have performed better in open primaries and caucuses, where their non-traditional voters can participate without the registration requirements and deadlines.</paragraph><paragraph>On Tuesday Florida is closed; Illinois and Missouri are open; North Carolina is open only to registered party members and independents; and Ohio requires voters to fill out party paperwork at the polls and affirm that they support the party's principles. </paragraph><paragraph>Sound complicated? Welcome to US-style democracy.</paragraph></body>

/news/world-asia-35808921.title: BBC News - Myanmar elects Htin Kyaw as first civilian president in decades
/news/world-asia-35808921.summary: Htin Kyaw is chosen by Myanmar's parliament as the country's first civilian president in 50 years, saying the victory belongs to Aung San Suu Kyi.
/news/world-asia-35808921.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/c649370f-2c10-f54f-ac2b-53f04385b7e8"><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="88769461">    <caption>When Myanmar's next president went to jail</caption>  </video><paragraph role="introduction">Myanmar's parliament has elected Htin Kyaw as the country's next president, the first civilian leader after more than 50 years of military rule.</paragraph><paragraph>Htin Kyaw is a close ally of Aung San Suu Kyi, whose National League for Democracy (NLD) party swept to victory in historic elections in November. </paragraph><paragraph>He said his appointment was "Aung San Suu Kyi's victory".</paragraph><paragraph>Ms Suu Kyi is barred from the post by the constitution, but has said she will lead the country anyway.</paragraph><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35809021 --><link><caption>How Suu Kyi could be more powerful outside the presidency</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-35754335"/></link></paragraph><paragraph>Htin Kyaw won with 360 of the 652 votes cast in the two houses of parliament, with MPs erupting into applause when the result was announced.</paragraph><paragraph>"Victory! This is sister Aung San Suu Kyi's victory. Thank you," Htin Kyaw said after winning.</paragraph><image id="75306515"/><crosshead>At the scene: Jonah Fisher, BBC News, Nay Pyi Taw</crosshead><image id="88774135"/><paragraph>The end result when it finally came was entirely as expected, with a landslide victory for Ms Suu Kyi's man, Htin Kyaw. </paragraph><paragraph>Given the miseries that this country has suffered this was another incredible momentous occasion. </paragraph><paragraph>But if she was enjoying it , or reflecting on the sacrifices that were made to get here, Ms Suu Kyi gave no indication. Just as she has done since the election in November, the former pro-democracy campaigner avoided the media and made no public comment. </paragraph><paragraph>No doubt acting on her instructions (probably a taste of what's to come) Htin Kyaw remained elusive. </paragraph><paragraph>The only time I saw Myanmar's next president was at the end of a cordoned-off corridor, waiting for the arrival of Ms Suu Kyi.</paragraph><image id="76020974"/><image id="88774689"/><paragraph>In second place was Myint Swe, who was nominated by the military and received 213 votes. A close ally of former junta leader Than Shwe, he is seen as a hardliner.</paragraph><paragraph>He was followed by Htin Kyaw's running mate and ethnic Chin candidate Henry Van Thio, who got 79 votes.</paragraph><paragraph>They will serve as first vice-president and second vice-president respectively.</paragraph><paragraph>The president is chosen from candidates put forward by each of the two houses of parliament, in addition to a third nominee from the military.</paragraph><image id="88671912"/><image id="76020974"/><crosshead>Who is Htin Kyaw?</crosshead>  <list type="unordered">    <listItem>Htin Kyaw, 70, is Ms Suu Kyi's close aide.</listItem>    <listItem>He is said to be a quietly spoken man who attended university in the UK. He has a reputation for honesty and loyalty, and has kept a low profile. </listItem>    <listItem>His father, the writer and poet Min Thu Wun, won a seat for the party at the 1990 election. </listItem>    <listItem>His wife, Su Su Lwin, is the daughter of an NLD founder, as well as being a sitting MP, and a prominent party member.</listItem>    <listItem>He has played a senior role at the Daw Khin Kyi Foundation, the charity founded in honour of Suu Kyi's late mother, and has been frequently seen at the NLD leader's side, serving as her driver from time to time.</listItem>  </list><image id="76020974"/><paragraph>The NLD has a huge majority in both houses of parliament, despite the military occupying 25% of seats, so the candidate it backed was all but guaranteed to win.</paragraph><paragraph>But correspondents warn of increasing confrontation in parliament in the future as MPs push against an army determined to hold onto the powers it has under the constitution.</paragraph><paragraph>It still controls key security ministries and also has the power to veto any changes to the constitution as that would require more than 75% of parliamentary votes. </paragraph><paragraph>Correspondents say that Htin Kyaw's election is widely supported among the Burmese people, as he has a solid reputation and is known to be trusted by Ms Suu Kyi. </paragraph><paragraph>Despite her popularity and prominence in Myanmar - also known as Burma - Ms Suu Kyi could not take the presidency herself.</paragraph><paragraph>A clause in the constitution, widely seen as being tailored against her, says anyone whose children have another nationality cannot become president. Her children hold British passports. </paragraph><paragraph>Despite weeks of negotiation prior to the vote, the NLD were unable to persuade the military to remove or suspend the clause to allow Ms Suu Kyi to take office.</paragraph><paragraph>However, Ms Suu Kyi has previously said that she would be "<!-- CPS Asset ID: 35809022 --><link><caption>above the president</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-34729659"/><url platform="enhancedmobile" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-34729659"/></link>" anyway, ruling through a proxy.</paragraph></body>
/news/world-asia-35808921.shortFormBody: <shortFormBody xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/c649370f-2c10-f54f-ac2b-53f04385b7e8"><paragraph>Myanmar's parliament has elected Htin Kyaw as the country's next president, the first civilian leader after more than 50 years of military rule.</paragraph><paragraph>Htin Kyaw is a close ally of Aung San Suu Kyi, whose National League for Democracy (NLD) party swept to victory in historic elections in November.</paragraph><paragraph>He said his appointment was "Aung San Suu Kyi's victory".</paragraph><paragraph>Ms Suu Kyi is barred from the post by the constitution, but has said she will lead the country anyway.</paragraph></shortFormBody>

/news/world-asia-35801526.title: BBC News - When Myanmar's next president went to jail
/news/world-asia-35801526.summary: What happened when Myanmar's next president, Htin Kyaw, tried to help Aung San Suu Kyi travel outside Yangon in 2000.
/news/world-asia-35801526.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/bff2d65b-719c-894b-a0bb-4a4e46775123"><paragraph>Myanmar has elected its first truly civilian president in more than 50 years. Htin Kyaw is a close aide of National League for Democracy leader and former political prisoner Aung San Suu Kyi. </paragraph><paragraph>He has not been a high profile figure in the struggle for democracy and generally avoided spending long periods in prison. </paragraph><paragraph>But 16 years ago he was arrested after trying to help Ms Suu Kyi travel outside Yangon.  Here his former fellow inmates tell us what happened and what they learned about Htin Kyaw in jail.</paragraph></body>

/sport/american-football/35809485.title: BBC Sport - Top NFL official acknowledges link between American football and CTE
/sport/american-football/35809485.summary: An NFL official acknowledges a link between head trauma in American football and the brain disease CTE.
/sport/american-football/35809485.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/a03a6d0d-893f-cf48-9427-78a2e63be8b5"><image id="88776534"/><paragraph role="introduction">A top NFL official has acknowledged a link between head trauma in American football and the brain disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE).</paragraph><paragraph>It is the first time a league executive has made such a concession.</paragraph><paragraph>Jeff Miller, the NFL's vice president of health and safety, was quizzed about CTE by United States politicians.</paragraph><paragraph>Asked whether there was a link between the game and neurodegenerative diseases like CTE, Miller replied: "The answer to that question is certainly yes."</paragraph><paragraph>In the build-up to Super Bowl 50 earlier this year, neurosurgeon Mitch Berger, who leads the NFL's subcommittee on long-term brain injury, said no link between American football and CTE had been established.</paragraph><image id="88776703"/><paragraph>Jan Schakowsky, who represents Illinois, was critical of Berger's comments, saying the league was "peddling a false sense of security" in downplaying the dangers of head trauma.</paragraph><paragraph>"Football is a high-risk sport because of the routine hits, not just diagnosable concussions," said Schakowsky. </paragraph><paragraph>"What the American public needs now is honesty about the health risks and clearly more research."</paragraph><paragraph>The NFL has previously acknowledged that head trauma, particularly concussion, poses a risk to the long-term health of players.</paragraph><paragraph>However, NFL commissioner Roger Goodell and other top officials have not made definitive public statements on the matter.</paragraph><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="88094749">    <caption>Goodell defends NFL concussion record</caption>  </video><paragraph>In giving his answers, Miller cited the work of Boston University neuropathologist Ann McKee.</paragraph><paragraph>She told committee members there is no doubt in her mind the illness, which can only be detected after death, is linked to playing football.</paragraph><paragraph>"I unequivocally think there's a link between playing football and CTE," said McKee. </paragraph><paragraph>"We've seen it in 90 out of 94 NFL players whose brains we've examined.</paragraph><paragraph>"We've found it in 45 out of 55 college players and six out of 26 high school players."</paragraph><paragraph>Some 5,000 former players have sued the NFL, claiming it hid the dangers of repeated head trauma. </paragraph><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35811316 --><link><caption>CTE</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bu.edu/cte/about/what-is-cte/"/></link> is associated with symptoms such as memory loss, depression and progressive dementia.  </paragraph><paragraph>The disease, which can only be diagnosed after death, has been found in the brains of dozens of former American football players.</paragraph></body>
/sport/american-football/35809485.shortFormBody: <shortFormBody xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/a03a6d0d-893f-cf48-9427-78a2e63be8b5"><paragraph>A top NFL official has acknowledged a link between head trauma in American football and the brain disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE).</paragraph><paragraph>It is the first time a league executive has made such a concession.</paragraph><paragraph>Jeff Miller, the NFL's vice president of health and safety, was quizzed about CTE by United States politicians.</paragraph><paragraph>Asked whether there was a link between the game and neurodegenerative diseases like CTE, Miller replied: "The answer to that question is certainly yes."</paragraph></shortFormBody>

/news/world-europe-35810521.title: BBC News - Murder investigation after car bomb kills driver in Berlin
/news/world-europe-35810521.summary: German police open a murder investigation after a bomb went off in a car in Berlin, killing the driver.
/news/world-europe-35810521.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/1eb1eba2-c09c-ea4a-9226-18838a82d3b3"><image id="88777301"/><paragraph role="introduction">Berlin police have launched a murder inquiry after car bomb exploded in a travelling vehicle, killing the driver.</paragraph><paragraph>The explosion occurred as the car moved through the western Charlottenburg district towards the centre. It flipped the vehicle into the air, police <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35813057 --><link><caption>said</caption><url platform="highweb" href="https://twitter.com/polizeiberlin/status/709661600333086720"/></link>. </paragraph><paragraph>They have identified the victim as a 43-year-old man of immigrant background. </paragraph><paragraph>Officials believe the blast was linked to organised crime and say there is <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35813347 --><link><caption>no evidence</caption><url platform="highweb" href="https://twitter.com/polizeiberlin/status/709712331807260672"/></link> of any link with terrorism.</paragraph><paragraph>However they do not know if the driver of the car was the intended target, a police spokesman said, quoted by German media.</paragraph><paragraph>The explosion happened "in or on" the front part of the Volkswagen Passat as it travelled along the Bismarckstrasse during the morning rush hour, a police spokesman said.</paragraph><paragraph>Police told residents in the area to close their windows and stay in the back of their apartments.</paragraph><paragraph>But bomb disposal teams later said there was no risk of more explosions.</paragraph><image id="88777682"/><image id="88777678"/><image id="88777674"/><image id="76020974"/><paragraph><bold>Are you in Berlin? Did you witness the explosion? If it is safe for you to do so, share your experiences. Email </bold><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35813062 --><link><caption>haveyoursay@bbc.co.uk</caption><url platform="highweb" href="mailto:haveyoursay@bbc.co.uk?subject=Berlin35810521"/><url platform="enhancedmobile" href="mailto:haveyoursay@bbc.co.uk?subject=Berlin35810521"/></link><bold> with your stories.</bold></paragraph><paragraph>Please include a contact number if you are willing to speak to a BBC journalist. You can also contact us in the following ways:</paragraph>  <list type="unordered">    <listItem>WhatsApp: <bold>+44 7525 900971</bold></listItem>    <listItem>Send pictures/video to <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35813059 --><link><caption>yourpics@bbc.co.uk</caption><url platform="highweb" href="mailto:yourpics@bbc.co.uk"/><url platform="enhancedmobile" href="mailto:yourpics@bbc.co.uk"/></link></listItem>    <listItem><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35813060 --><link><caption>Upload your pictures / video here</caption><altText>Your news, your pictures</altText><url platform="highweb" href="http://upload.news.bbc.cs.streamuk.com/"/><url platform="enhancedmobile" href="http://upload.news.bbc.cs.streamuk.com/"/></link></listItem>    <listItem>Tweet: <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35813061 --><link><caption>@BBC_HaveYourSay</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://twitter.com/BBC_HaveYourSay"/><url platform="enhancedmobile" href="http://twitter.com/BBC_HaveYourSay"/></link></listItem>    <listItem>Send an SMS or MMS to <bold>61124</bold> or <bold>+44 7624 800 100 </bold></listItem>  </list></body>
/news/world-europe-35810521.shortFormBody: <shortFormBody xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/1eb1eba2-c09c-ea4a-9226-18838a82d3b3"><paragraph>Berlin police have launched a murder inquiry after car bomb exploded in a travelling vehicle, killing the driver.</paragraph><paragraph>The explosion occurred as the car moved through the western Charlottenburg district towards the centre. It flipped the vehicle into the air, police said.</paragraph><paragraph>They have identified the victim as a 43-year-old man of immigrant background.</paragraph><paragraph>Officials believe the blast was linked to organised crime and say there is no evidence of any link with terrorism.</paragraph></shortFormBody>

/news/business-35809798.title: BBC News - Bangladesh bank boss Atiur Rahman quits over $100m cyber-fraud
/news/business-35809798.summary: The head of Bangladesh's central bank resigns after cyber-thieves stole more than $100m from the country's foreign currency reserves.
/news/business-35809798.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/dccdacff-8f67-3a48-bca7-19806f9faabb"><image id="88686926"/><paragraph role="introduction">The head of Bangladesh's central bank, Atiur Rahman, has resigned after cyber-thieves stole more than $100m from the country's foreign currency reserves.</paragraph><paragraph>Mr Rahman submitted his resignation to Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina after it emerged that unknown hackers had stolen the money from the bank's account with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.</paragraph><paragraph>The theft happened in February, but Mr Rahman did not tell the government.</paragraph><paragraph>Finance Minister A M A Muhith said he had learnt of it from press reports.</paragraph><paragraph>According to media reports quoting banking officials, the gang behind the raid used stolen credentials to make requests to transfer cash look legitimate.</paragraph><paragraph>If all the requests had gone unchallenged, the gang would have got away with about $1bn.</paragraph><paragraph>However, the transfers were stopped when the volume of requests raised suspicions at other banks.</paragraph><crosshead>Spelling mistake</crosshead><paragraph>To commit the attack, the gang spent time studying the internal processes of Bangladesh's central bank, so they could convincingly pose as officials when requesting the transfers.</paragraph><paragraph>However, the sheer number of transactions and a spelling mistake helped alert bank staff to the theft.</paragraph><paragraph>The spelling mistake in the name of one recipient of funds led Deutsche Bank, which was helping to route the cash, to ask for clarification from the central bank, which then stopped the transaction. </paragraph><paragraph>At about the same time, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York had alerted the Bangladesh central bank to a series of suspicious requests to transfer money. The requests are believed to have been flagged because they were to private accounts rather than other banks and because there were so many of them.</paragraph><paragraph>The money that the hackers did steal ended up in accounts in Sri Lanka and the Philippines. </paragraph><paragraph>Part of the money was recovered from Sri Lanka, but the rest was laundered through casinos in the Philippines. The central bank said it was working with authorities there to recover the remaining amount.</paragraph><paragraph>Bangladesh's government has publicly blamed the New York Fed for not spotting the suspicious transactions earlier. </paragraph></body>
/news/business-35809798.shortFormBody: <shortFormBody xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/dccdacff-8f67-3a48-bca7-19806f9faabb"><paragraph>The head of Bangladesh's central bank, Atiur Rahman, has resigned after cyber-thieves stole more than $100m from the country's foreign currency reserves.</paragraph><paragraph>Mr Rahman submitted his resignation to Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina after it emerged that unknown hackers had stolen the money from the bank's account with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.</paragraph><paragraph>The theft happened in February, but Mr Rahman did not tell the government.</paragraph><paragraph>Finance Minister A M A Muhith said he had learnt of it from press reports.</paragraph></shortFormBody>

/news/world-africa-34830724.title: BBC News - Cyber-crime is Africa's 'next big threat', experts warn
/news/world-africa-34830724.summary: Government and commercial online services could become the next frontier for illegal activity in Africa as many websites are insecure, experts warn.
/news/world-africa-34830724.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/9276a1bd-4162-9e4a-9663-612f80c5f0e8"><image id="86704944"/><paragraph role="introduction">Government and commercial online services could become the next frontier for illegal activity in Africa, security experts are warning.</paragraph><paragraph>As more people get access to the internet across Africa, governments and businesses are increasing their online presence but there are questions about how secure these websites are. </paragraph><paragraph>The email scam using a message from someone pretending to be a relative of a dead African leader asking for bank details is well known, but now tactics have changed.</paragraph><paragraph>Today's cyber-criminals do not need users' approval or awareness to access valuable data, which could lead to the theft of a large amount of money.</paragraph><paragraph>For example, a <!-- CPS Asset ID: 34834403 --><link><caption>recent cybersecurity report on Kenya</caption><altText>Linkn to cyber-security report</altText><url platform="highweb" href="http://serianu.com/downloads/KenyaCyberSecurityReport2015.pdf"/></link> says businesses are losing about $146m (£96m) every year to cyber-crime.</paragraph><paragraph>Kenyan cybersecurity analyst Freddy (not his real name) showed me how the average Kenyan website lacks adequate protection. </paragraph><image id="86704946"/><paragraph>Working on a dummy site with a typical level of security, he showed me how it was possible to hack into it. </paragraph><paragraph>"This will take me about 15 minutes," he said as he typed away, writing code. </paragraph><paragraph>As predicted, in just a quarter of an hour, he had full access to the database and was able to change the administrator password and upload his own material.</paragraph><paragraph>Freddy is one of the good hackers who advises companies and defends them from attacks rather than exploits the problems, but he feels the response to the online risks is inadequate. </paragraph><paragraph>This situation is replicated across the continent. </paragraph><paragraph>South Africa's <!-- CPS Asset ID: 34834404 --><link><caption>Sunday Times newspaper reported that hackers launched 6,000 cyber-attacks against South African infrastructure</caption><altText>Link to newspaper story</altText><url platform="highweb" href="http://m.timeslive.co.za/thetimes/?articleId=15801457"/></link>, internet service providers (ISPs) and businesses in October alone.</paragraph><image id="86715359"/><paragraph>Bright Mawudor, a Ghanaian cybersecurity expert at Pukyong National University in South Korea, says that most African banks, government agencies and ISPs, in the face of competition, prioritise what their website can do and how fast new features can be released to the public. </paragraph><paragraph>Security is an afterthought, he argues.</paragraph><paragraph>"These websites are usually outsourced to software development companies who get pressured to deliver quickly," he says. </paragraph><paragraph>"Something that should take about a month has to be delivered in a week and is thus sub-standard. They always make a mistake and the hacker just has to find one." </paragraph><crosshead>Government website threat</crosshead><paragraph>Rather than creating their own systems from scratch, there is a tendency to take a shortcut and use existing popular templates, which Mr Mawudor says can easily be breached. </paragraph><paragraph>He says he knows of several African governments that use these for their websites that can contain sensitive information including individuals' personal details, which can be used for identity theft.</paragraph><paragraph>According to the recent Kenyan cybersecurity report, most African-based businesses, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises, are unable to withstand cyber-attacks. </paragraph><paragraph>"If there was the threat of a physical attack you would see a lot of fences and guards," says William Makatiani of Serianu Limited which was behind the report. </paragraph><paragraph>"Unfortunately with cyber-attacks, very few people can detect them and you can go for up to a year without knowing you've been attacked."</paragraph><image id="86715361"/><paragraph>At the Serianu offices in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi, big screens show world maps with yellow spots appearing in different countries representing cyber-attacks happening in real time. </paragraph><paragraph>As these continue, Mr Makatiani suggests the main reason some companies are waking up to the threat is because they are losing money, but he says they are only disclosing these incidents discreetly. </paragraph><paragraph>The types of crimes are also becoming more sophisticated - moving from password theft, to stealing credit card details to attacks on computer networks.</paragraph><paragraph>Even if the worst-affected businesses like banks and insurance companies improved their security, the ISPs are accused of not doing enough to create sufficient security for the small businesses they serve.</paragraph><image id="86102404"/><paragraph>South Africa recently opened a virtual cybersecurity hub in its capital, Pretoria, to help business, government and civil society work together on responses to these incidents. </paragraph><paragraph>Research firm Columinate suggests that South Africa is one of the world's cybercrime hotspots. </paragraph><paragraph>State Security Minister David Mahlobo pointed out that for the country to be adequately protected, there needs to be more awareness of the threats.</paragraph><crosshead>Challenging hackers</crosshead><paragraph>This situation is mirrored across the continent and has led Mr Mawudor to help found Africahackon, a forum bringing together cyber-security experts, from university to corporate level, to discuss how to take the initiative on these issues, rather than wait for the security gaps to be exploited. </paragraph><paragraph>The group works with a lot of young people with newly-acquired computer skills who might otherwise be tempted to use them for illegal activity online. </paragraph><paragraph>"You can never stop cyber-attacks but you can employ the best practices to curb them," says Mr Mawudor. </paragraph><paragraph>"This will be a process over time and not a one-day event."</paragraph></body>

/news/technology-34474883.title: BBC News - How Minecraft undermined my digital defences
/news/technology-34474883.summary: Thanks to my children, block-building game Minecraft almost turned out to be the weak link in my digital defences.
/news/technology-34474883.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/4fd87b56-decb-fb45-91b8-97d73c5542cd"><image id="88633269"/><paragraph role="introduction">Could your children be your weak link when it comes to home security? One of mine almost was thanks to Minecraft.</paragraph><paragraph>One of my boys wanted to install a mod for it and needed me to approve it. And as I am paranoid about what runs on our main computer, I oversaw the whole process.</paragraph><paragraph>At first, it all looked fine. </paragraph><paragraph>There are thousands of mods or add-ons for Minecraft that make a variety of changes to the game. Some add new blocks, others change the way it looks and some turn it into an entirely different game. </paragraph><paragraph>The one he wanted was hard to find, despite it being popular among his friends. When we found it, I was not sure we were getting it from the person who actually created it.</paragraph><paragraph>I was suspicious because the site was festooned with buttons that looked like they would start the download but instead led to dead ends populated by links to download accelerators and other utilities we did not want. Grubby ads blinked alongside. I'm not sure mature Russian women are keen to meet my 12-year-old son.</paragraph><image id="74982321"/><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35752731 --><link><caption>Cybersecurity Alert special index</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-28549494"/></link></paragraph><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35758891 --><link><caption>Is your phone listening to you?</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-35639549"/></link></paragraph><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35752732 --><link><caption>How to hack the average home</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-35629890"/></link></paragraph><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35752733 --><link><caption>Hanging out with the script kiddies</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-32019260"/></link></paragraph><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35752734 --><link><caption>Ukraine blackout hacks 'could happen elsewhere'</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-35686493"/></link></paragraph><image id="74982321"/><image id="88633273"/><paragraph>After a few dead ends, we clicked the right link but then had to wait while we were put through several re-directs and a pop-up page that could not be shut down if we wanted the mod. </paragraph><paragraph>We did, so we stuck with it and the download started. And kept going. And going. Which was odd given it was only a few megabytes in size. My suspicions aroused, I killed the download over my son's protests. It was just as well. Running it through an online malware scanner revealed that though it was not actively malicious it would have installed adware and hijacked searches.</paragraph><paragraph>Definitely not the mod we wanted.</paragraph><crosshead>Big target</crosshead><paragraph>Soon afterwards, I found a warning about the page saying it was fake. That warning was circulated by <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35752730 --><link><caption>the Stop Mod Reposts campaign</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://stopmodreposts.org/"/></link>. It is attempting to stop popular mods being hijacked by conmen, virus writers and cyber-thieves.  It maintains a long, long list of the scam pages offering re-packaged mods. It even makes an extension for web browsers that warns when you stray on to a dodgy site.</paragraph><paragraph>"Minecraft is a huge target," said Chris Boyd, a security researcher at Malwarebytes and a veteran scam-spotter. He has seen fake sites offering the game for free, fake pages asking visitors to log in with their Minecraft name and password as well as a variety of other scams offering skins, capes and cheats.</paragraph><paragraph>But, he said, there was a long history of cyber-conmen going after children and the things they do online. He remembers seeing scams in 1999 that targeted the economy around Neopets - digital creatures popular with younger web users. </paragraph><image id="74982321"/><crosshead>Staying safe online</crosshead><paragraph>Keep all software up-to-date and patched. Use anti-virus and anti-spyware software. And a firewall.</paragraph><paragraph>Give your children an account on a PC or laptop that restricts what they can install. </paragraph><paragraph>Use strong passwords (mix letters, numbers and symbols) and do not share them. Not even with friends.</paragraph><paragraph>Be wary of links offered in chat forums or in-game.</paragraph><paragraph>Talk to your children about what is appropriate behaviour. </paragraph><paragraph>Choose neutral user names. Use different login details on different sites.</paragraph><paragraph>Do not reveal personal information, even to those who are being friendly.</paragraph><paragraph>Be sceptical of flashy ads and links to games, cheats, and freebies that offer in-game currencies.</paragraph><paragraph>Check if there is a way to restrict who children play with online. Check online privacy settings to see with whom data is being shared.</paragraph><image id="74982321"/><paragraph>Younger gamers are regularly targeted, said Mark James of security firm Eset and many inadvertently give away their age with the names they choose when they sign up to a site or service.</paragraph><paragraph>Scammers and conmen can lurk in forums offering advice and links to extras, cheats and advice pages that are actually laced with malware. </paragraph><paragraph>"Often in-game chat channels play host to predators waiting for that click on a 'bad' link that infects a device," he said.</paragraph><paragraph>There is evidence that lurking on a gaming service pays off for the bad guys. Valve, which runs the massively popular Steam gaming service, revealed late last year that 77,000 accounts for the service are being hijacked each month. Control of those accounts will be lost via Steam's chat system or through booby-trapped links.</paragraph><image id="88633271"/><paragraph>Mr James warned against befriending people on social media just to get "freebies" for games and said parents needed to educate children about safe browsing and gaming and what information was appropriate to share.</paragraph><paragraph>Without this, he said, children can be an easy target.</paragraph><paragraph>"If they want that mod or add-on they will do almost anything to get it," he said. "Unfortunately many young people do not have the perspective to see what long-term damage could be done if they are caught out."</paragraph><paragraph>Statistics from security firm Symantec suggest that younger people are getting hit regularly. A report it produced in early 2016 revealed that a quarter of parents have had a child or know someone with a child whose actions compromised the family's online security.</paragraph><paragraph>Jacqueline Beauchere, Microsoft's chief online safety officer, said scammers go to great lengths to catch children out.</paragraph><paragraph>"Young people are easily enticed to click flashy advertisements, visit unofficial websites of popular celebrities, download so-called 'free' games, and tap 'Agree', 'OK', or 'I accept' to quickly get to where and what they want to online," she said. "Many of these actions are just notorious pathways to viruses, spyware and other malicious software."</paragraph><paragraph>The scammers went after children, said Ms Beauchere, because of the cache of valuable loot that one mistake might lead them to.</paragraph><image id="88633275"/><paragraph>"Among criminals, personal and financial data about any and all individuals has become the sought-after 'currency' of the web," she said. Cyber-thieves targeted children only to get at this data, she said. </paragraph><paragraph>Mr Boyd from Malwarebtyes agreed. And, he said, what helped the scammers was the way children typically get online. </paragraph><paragraph>"A lot of kids play via their parents tablets, laptops and desktops," he said. "It's quite likely that parents will re-use login details on other accounts. And there's likely to be a payment method attached to it."</paragraph><paragraph>That is the data they are after, he said.</paragraph><paragraph>What makes this tougher to police, he said, is that children often know more than their parents about the technology. That competence can fool many parents into thinking their offspring are safer online than they actually are. </paragraph><paragraph>"I would be surprised if parents know much about how the technology works," he said.</paragraph><paragraph>But, he added, staying safe is not impossible. It takes collaboration between parents and children. Both need to educate the other about what they do and how to stay safe. </paragraph></body>

/news/world-asia-india-35809467.title: BBC News - Outrage after India politician 'assaults' police horse
/news/world-asia-india-35809467.summary: Police in India lodge a case against a politician from the ruling BJP party for allegedly assaulting and badly injuring a police horse during a protest.
/news/world-asia-india-35809467.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/b79cc027-d951-e14a-8749-c53e652eda66"><image id="88773584"/><paragraph role="introduction">Police in India have lodged a case against a politician from the ruling BJP for allegedly attacking a police horse during a protest in the northern state of Uttarakhand.</paragraph><paragraph>Ganesh Joshi, a legislator from the hill town of Mussoorie, allegedly assaulted the animal with a stick.</paragraph><paragraph>The horse, named Shaktimaan, suffered multiple fractures and some reports said it might require a leg amputation.</paragraph><paragraph>Mr Joshi said the charge against him was politically motivated.</paragraph><paragraph>"The footage which the electronic media is showing by linking with an old clip - in which I am lifting a stick in front of the horse - has no connection at all [to the incident]," Mr Joshi told the BBC. </paragraph><paragraph>"The horse fell down when someone pulled its saddle and the animal sustained a fracture on its leg," he added.</paragraph><paragraph>The incident took place near the legislative assembly in the state capital, Dehradun, on Monday when the BJP was holding a protest against the Congress party-led state government.</paragraph><paragraph>The horse is being treated by veterinary officers and reports say it is in a serious condition. </paragraph><paragraph>The incident has caused outrage in India with many taking to social media to express their anger.</paragraph><paragraph>On Twitter, the hashtag #IsHorseAntiNational, prompted by a tongue in cheek <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35809109 --><link><caption>newspaper headline</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/bjp-mla-ganesh-joshi-protests-by-beating-up-police-horse/1/619944.html"/></link> that read, "BJP MLA beats up a horse. No confirmation whether the horse was anti-national", has been trending since Tuesday morning.</paragraph><paragraph>The term "anti-national" is being used in reference to the recent arrest of several students of a top university for allegedly shouting "anti-India" slogans. </paragraph><paragraph>The government defended the arrests by saying the students were "anti-national".</paragraph><image id="88773842"/><image id="88773844"/><image id="88773846"/><image id="88773848"/></body>
/news/world-asia-india-35809467.shortFormBody: <shortFormBody xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/b79cc027-d951-e14a-8749-c53e652eda66"><paragraph>Police in India have lodged a case against a politician from the ruling BJP for allegedly attacking a police horse during a protest in the northern state of Uttarakhand.</paragraph><paragraph>Ganesh Joshi, a legislator from the hill town of Mussoorie, allegedly assaulted the animal with a stick.</paragraph><paragraph>The horse, named Shaktimaan, suffered multiple fractures and some reports said it might require a leg amputation.</paragraph><paragraph>Mr Joshi said the charge against him was politically motivated.</paragraph></shortFormBody>

88773584.caption: Shaktimaan, the white police horse, is being treated by veterinary officers

88773842.altText: What is the CRIME of the horse?! #IsHorseAntiNational

88773844.altText: #IsHorseAntiNational BJP MLA should be booked and action taken against him according to Law. Party should throw him out immediately.

88773846.altText: How can anyone be so thuggish as this BJP MLA who broke a poor animal's leg? #IsHorseAntiNational

88773848.altText: If they attacked the police they wud hv been jailed for obstruction to govt servant. But the horse was on govt duty too #IsHorseAntiNational

/sport/tennis/35808571.title: BBC Sport - Tennis match-fixing: 'More players should be investigated'
/sport/tennis/35808571.summary: More than two dozen top tennis players should be investigated for possible links to betting rings, an Italian prosecutor says.
/sport/tennis/35808571.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/bbe25fde-6105-6b4f-b9b7-e740ac5f1d35"><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="88768835">    <caption>Italian prosecutor Roberto di Martino has called for top tennis players to be investigated</caption>  </video><paragraph role="introduction">More than two dozen top tennis players should be investigated for possible links to betting rings, according to an Italian prosecutor.</paragraph><paragraph>Roberto di Martino says their names have appeared in evidence seized from gamblers suspected of fixing matches.</paragraph><paragraph>They include two players who have been ranked in the world's top 20.</paragraph><paragraph>So far, only Potito Starace and Daniele Bracciali, two Italians, have been investigated and charged but Di Martino says others should be investigated.</paragraph><paragraph>He also told the BBC's <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35809483 --><link><caption>File on 4 programme</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b006th08"/></link> and BuzzFeed News that tennis authorities should be doing more with the evidence he has gathered.</paragraph><paragraph>"Surely if these foreign players were Italian, they would certainly have been at least questioned," Di Martino said. "They should have provided some explanations."</paragraph>  <list type="unordered">    <listItem>Listen to Simon Cox's report for <bold>File on 4</bold> at 20:00 GMT on Tuesday on Radio 4, or <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35809484 --><link><caption>catch up on the BBC iPlayer</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b07378dc"/></link></listItem>  </list><paragraph>Di Martino has been conducting a two-year inquiry into a suspected match-fixing ring involving Italian tennis players and gamblers.</paragraph><paragraph>His inquiry has obtained internet chat logs and recordings of phone calls between players and gamblers.</paragraph><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="88768926">    <caption>A former top-50 tennis player had an exchange of Skype messages with a gambler offering him a match-fixing deal</caption>  </video><paragraph>He says more than two dozen non-Italian players are mentioned by the gamblers and believes these players should be investigated by the <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35807930 --><link><caption>Tennis Integrity Unit (TIU).</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.tennisintegrityunit.com/"/></link></paragraph><paragraph>He would not reveal the identity of the players mentioned in the seized evidence but he added: "Interestingly, they are not so-called second-tier tennis players, but also players of some importance."</paragraph><paragraph>Starace and Bracciali have been accused of conspiring to fix matches between 2007 and 2011 for up to 50,000 euros (£38,800).</paragraph><paragraph>They are due to appear in court in May and deny charges of conspiracy to commit sports fraud.</paragraph><paragraph>Di Martino claims he has "concrete evidence" about two specific matches in 2009 and 2011 in Barcelona involving Starace.</paragraph><paragraph>He suspects there are 30 other matches that may have been corrupted, by a number of players, including at Wimbledon and the French Open. </paragraph><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="88767925">    <caption>Paola Cesaroni: "They had to protect some names we think because they were high-ranked players"</caption>  </video><paragraph>The BBC and BuzzFeed News have learned the names of the players contained in Di Martino's investigation files.</paragraph><paragraph>A source close to the inquiry said two of these players had been described in an internet chat log between two gamblers as their "horses".</paragraph><paragraph>The source told us using this term could mean the players were under the control of the gamblers.</paragraph><paragraph>These chat logs were among hundreds of files prosecutors sent to the TIU three months ago.</paragraph><paragraph>But Di Martino said TIU investigators had visited him and made it clear they were "exclusively" interested in the Italian players.</paragraph><paragraph>"The international aspect seems more problematic than a situation involving a few Italian players," he said.</paragraph><paragraph>"It would be possible to identify, possibly hit, many foreign players who definitely are part of this system."</paragraph><image id="88771277"/><paragraph>Di Martino criticised the TIU for failing to act on hundreds of alerts it has received about suspicious betting on tennis matches.</paragraph><paragraph>"I do not understand why there was no real initiative by the integrity unit to establish if there was something dirty behind this," he said. </paragraph><paragraph>Tennis has been accused of covering up evidence about widespread gambling on matches by players.</paragraph><paragraph>In January, tennis authorities launched an inquiry into corruption after the BBC and Buzzfeed News <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35807929 --><link><caption>revealed the TIU had failed to act</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/tennis/35319202"/></link> on repeated warnings about 16 top players suspected of being involved in throwing matches.</paragraph><paragraph>The TIU said in a statement that it "acts on all evidence" as part of its "a long-standing and total commitment to eradicating betting-related corruption in the sport".</paragraph><paragraph>It said it was investigating the allegations against Bracciali and Starace. </paragraph></body>
/sport/tennis/35808571.shortFormBody: <shortFormBody xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/bbe25fde-6105-6b4f-b9b7-e740ac5f1d35"><paragraph>More than two dozen top tennis players should be investigated for possible links to betting rings, according to an Italian prosecutor.</paragraph><paragraph>Roberto di Martino says their names have appeared in evidence seized from gamblers suspected of fixing matches.</paragraph><paragraph>They include two players who have been ranked in the world's top 20.</paragraph><paragraph>So far, only Potito Starace and Daniele Bracciali, two Italians, have been investigated and charged but Di Martino says others should be investigated.</paragraph></shortFormBody>

/sport/tennis/35808571.headline: Tennis match-fixing: 'More players should be investigated'

/news/magazine-35802893.title: BBC News - The gambler and the top-50 tennis players
/news/magazine-35802893.summary: An Italian investigation into match-fixing in tennis is laying bare the efforts of a gambling syndicate that tried to fix matches around the world.
/news/magazine-35802893.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/221d60aa-c6a2-3549-9405-e46f84fdfe65"><image id="88766000"/><paragraph role="introduction">An Italian investigation is laying bare the efforts of a gambling syndicate that tried to fix tennis matches around the world, including at Wimbledon and the French Open. Documents seen by the BBC and Buzzfeed News suggest the gamblers approached two leading Italian players - but prosecutors say there is evidence they courted many others, including two who have been in the world's top 20. </paragraph><paragraph>Roberto di Martino sits back in his chair, his face creasing into a tight smile, pushing up his thin wire-rimmed glasses. I have just asked if I can look inside some of the dozens of manila folders of evidence about tennis match fixing piled around his vast office, beneath a fresco-covered ceiling. He shakes his head firmly, putting away the papers closest to me on his desk. </paragraph><paragraph>In May, he will present his evidence in court against two former Italian tennis players, Potito Starace and Daniele Bracciali, who are accused of conspiring to fix matches with Italian gamblers.</paragraph><image id="88767455"/><paragraph>It has taken a long time to get the case this far. </paragraph><paragraph>The prosecutor from the northern Italian city of Cremona never set out to investigate tennis. In 2011, when police raided the home of Manlio Bruni, an accountant and gambler from Bologna, it was for involvement in a football corruption scam. He was placed under house arrest and his computers were seized.</paragraph><paragraph>But as investigators waded through the thousands of Skype instant messages on Bruni's computer they realised he was trying to corrupt tennis players.  Working with Buzzfeed News and the Italian newspaper, Il Sole 24 Ore, the BBC has obtained hundreds of pages of the evidence Di Martino chose not to reveal. </paragraph><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="88768926">    <caption>A former top-50 player exchanges Skype messages with a gambler offering him a match-fixing deal</caption>  </video><paragraph>In July 2007 Bruni began chatting on Skype to Daniele Bracciali, who had at one time been one of the world's top-50 players. They had been introduced by a mutual contact, who said Bracciali might be interested in fixing a match. </paragraph><paragraph>When Bruni decided to test him out, Bracciali was in the US, playing in the Newport tournament. He said it was "extremely important to win the first set, and if possible, to go a break ahead in the second… would that be possible?... in this case I can give you much more". </paragraph><paragraph>Bracciali refused, so Bruni tried again. "OK, I could do 50 to begin with for tomorrow but it is absolutely necessary that you win the first set." By 50 he meant 50,000 euros (£39,000). Bracciali said he didn't know his opponent so it would be difficult to arrange to win the first set, and he told Bruni:  "90% of me says no... but if I change my mind I will let you know."</paragraph><paragraph>Bruni finished by promising 60,000 euros (£46,000) if Bracciali changed his mind. He said he couldn't do it, repeating that "it would be easier" if he knew his opponent.</paragraph><paragraph>This was the start of a relationship that would last for four years until Bruni's arrest in 2011. During this period, prosecutors say, the gambling syndicate Bruni was a member of would try to corrupt countless other players in Italy and abroad. </paragraph><image id="88767423"/><paragraph>This wasn't the first time Bracciali had been tapped up by match-fixers. Years earlier, his family and friends had gathered in the bar of his tennis club, just outside the ancient walls of the Tuscan town of Arezzo. They were there to watch Bracciali play in the French Open, the local boy made good. Just hours before the match he called his father to say he had been offered $50,000 (£35,000) to throw the match. Also at the club was Paola Cesaroni, mother of another local tennis star, Federico Luzzi. She recalls how Bracciali's father was furious. </paragraph><paragraph>He told his son, "Don't do it, because tonight the whole town of Arezzo, all the supporters of your club are in front of a TV waiting for your match. So play, and win," Cesaroni says. This is exactly what Bracciali did. </paragraph><paragraph>Bracciali says he rebuffed Bruni's approaches too, and he denies any involvement in match-fixing. He told the police that he played along and faked interest - though one source close to the investigation says, "You might fake for a month but you don't do it for four years." </paragraph><paragraph>Bruni later told prosecutors: "I actually tried to corrupt him by offering him 50,000 euros if he won the first set and lost the other two during the game." Although Bracciali declined to fix this match, Bruni said that Bracciali "declared himself available to contact the Italian tennis players he knew, to get them to do what I asked, altering in whole or in part the result of the matches". </paragraph><paragraph>Bracciali first tried his sometime doubles partner, Potito Starace, who was then ranked number 31 in the world.  According to prosecutors, Starace agreed to work with Bracciali and Bruni from the end of 2007. Prosecutors claim Bracciali communicated with the gamblers while Starace carried out the fixes on court. </paragraph><image id="88767454"/><paragraph>In December 2007 Bruni informed other gamblers in his syndicate: "We bought Potito." Starace was promised between 30,000 and 50,000 euros (£23,000 to £39,000) for each match he agreed to fix. Bruni told prosecutors he even provided Sim cards so the players could speak to him without being detected. Prosecutors claim this went on until 2011. Potito Starace strenuously denies any contact with gamblers or involvement in match-fixing. </paragraph><paragraph>In the computers seized by the police, the gamblers discussed about 30 matches, including at Wimbledon and the French Open. But there are two matches in particular, according to chief Cremona prosecutor Roberto di Martino, "for which we have very concrete indications that they have been manipulated".</paragraph><image id="88733422"/><paragraph><bold>Find out more</bold></paragraph><paragraph>Listen to Simon Cox's report for <bold>File on 4</bold> at 20:00 on Tuesday on BBC Radio 4, or <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35808159 --><link><caption>catch up later on the BBC iPlayer</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b07378dc"/></link></paragraph><image id="88733422"/><paragraph>The first of these matches took place in May 2009. Manlio Bruni told police he had offered Starace 50,000 euros to lose against the lower-ranked German, Daniel Brands. The gamblers used several accounts to place bets that Starace would lose, but the betting company, Betfair, thought the betting looked suspect and refused to pay out their winnings when Starace lost. Bruni told the police the syndicate only made between 15,000 and 20,000 euros (£12,000 - £15,000) from the match but they decided to give this to Starace anyway and delivered it to him in cash at a tournament in Italy. There is no suggestion that Brands was aware that anything might be amiss.</paragraph><paragraph>Bruni checked with another gambler on Skype: "Did he like the cash?" The gambler replied he still hadn't seen it but added: "Braccio [Bracciali] told me that he was very happy."</paragraph><image id="88766002"/><paragraph>The second match took place in April 2011. Starace was taking on the Spaniard, Daniel Gimeno-Traver, in Barcelona and was offered 25,000 euros (£19,000) to lose, but double that if he won the first set and went on to lose the match. Starace withdrew and forfeited the match after winning the first set. He denies fixing this match or any other game. </paragraph><paragraph>A week before this match Starace had reached an ATP final in Casablanca. It was a big deal for him, a singles final. Bruni received a call about the game from a fellow gambler. He said Starace had taken 300,000 euros (£232,000) to lose. "I remained astonished," Bruni told the police. "Starace had always said that he would have been able to lose a first or second round but never a final."</paragraph><quoteBox><quote><quoteText>The international events seem more problematic than those situations in which, after all, only a few Italian players were involved</quoteText><quoteSource title="Cremona prosecutor">Roberto di Martino</quoteSource></quote></quoteBox><paragraph>After receiving the call Bruni checked with Bracciali who said the idea Starace would throw a final was nonsense. In the end Starace did lose. Bruni told prosecutors: "When I saw the result, the world fell apart."</paragraph><paragraph>Sources close to the investigation suspect that Starace was trying to work with a bigger, richer gambling syndicate. This part of the files was leaked to an Italian newspaper and Starace was furious when he read it. When he was interviewed by investigators in October 2014 he stated, "I emphatically deny any arrangement to lose a match in a tournament."   </paragraph><paragraph>While the prosecutor was investigating Bruni's links with Bracciali and Starace, the Italian Tennis Federation used some of this evidence in 2015 to ban the two players for life for match-fixing. Starace's ban was later overturned and Bracciali's reduced to a year because the appeal panel said the evidence wasn't strong enough. The Cremona prosecutor had already reached this conclusion and decided to base his case on different matches. The players face another possible hit, though, as the Tennis Integrity Unit (TIU) - the sport's own anti-corruption body - has also been running an investigation into the players since 2014. So far no action has been against them internationally. </paragraph><paragraph>But arguably the TIU should be using the Italian investigation to look into other players linked to gamblers, not just Bracciali and Starace.</paragraph><paragraph>As the Cremona prosecutor Roberto Di Martino ploughed through the thousands of documents, he realised this was not solely an Italian problem.</paragraph><image id="88767458"/><paragraph>He noticed the names of top foreign players being discussed by the gamblers and scams they were proposing. As a tennis fan their names leaped out at him. Some of these players featured in an earlier BBC/Buzzfeed News investigation which revealed the world <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35808158 --><link><caption>tennis authorities failed to act on repeated warnings</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-35325473"/></link> about 16 top-level players taking part in suspicious matches. </paragraph><paragraph>In one conversation in February 2011 a discussion takes place about two players who have been in the world's top 20, who the gamblers call their "horses".  One gambler says he has a conflict of interest as "one of my horses is in the final" and his "other one is in the semi-final".  He goes on to claim he is friends with one of the players and "I have the pass as member of his staff", before adding ominously, "slowly my horses are coming to papa".  A source close to the enquiry said referring to "horses" could refer to players who brought gamblers luck or alternatively that the players were under their control. </paragraph><paragraph>Roberto Di Martino refuses to name any of these non-Italian players, but says there is enough evidence in his files for investigators to question them, at the very least to find out if they were approached by gamblers.</paragraph><paragraph>He has limited ability to do this, so has handed all of his files to the TIU. But when they visited him three months ago they were only interested in the Italian players. He found this surprising and alarming. </paragraph><paragraph>"The international events seem more problematic than those situations in which, after all, only a few Italian players were involved," he says. This was not a case of "one single situation in which shadows were cast on important tennis players. The problem is that there are many situations, then it cannot be an accident, it cannot be a coincidence."</paragraph><paragraph>Nigel Willerton, director of integrity at the TIU said it "acts on all evidence of corruption". In January, following the BBC's revelations, an independent review panel was set up to look into match-fixing. Mr Willerton said: "This wide-ranging remit will allow it to investigate all and any allegations of corrupt practice." </paragraph><paragraph><italic>Subscribe to the </italic><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35802894 --><link><caption>BBC News Magazine's email newsletter</caption><url platform="highweb" href="https://ssl.bbc.co.uk/newsletters/newsmagazine?ptrt=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine"/></link><italic> to get articles sent to your inbox.</italic></paragraph></body>

/news/world-europe-35809891.title: BBC News - Mother Teresa to be made a saint, Pope Francis announces
/news/world-europe-35809891.summary: Mother Teresa, the nun who worked with the poor in the Indian city of Kolkata, will be declared a saint on 4 September, Pope Francis announces.
/news/world-europe-35809891.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/b853ebb5-049f-c14c-bfab-98acc7797835"><image id="88773974"/><paragraph role="introduction">Mother Teresa, the Roman Catholic nun who worked with the poor in the Indian city of Kolkata (Calcutta) is to be declared a saint on 4 September, Pope Francis has announced.</paragraph><paragraph>She founded a sisterhood that runs 19 homes, and won the Nobel Peace Prize.</paragraph><paragraph>She died in 1997 - aged 87 - and was beatified in 2003, the first step to sainthood.</paragraph><paragraph>The Pope cleared the way for sainthood last year when he recognised a second miracle attributed to Mother Teresa.</paragraph><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35812842 --><link><caption>Mother Teresa - the 'Living Saint'</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-35130795"/></link></paragraph><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35812843 --><link><caption>How to become a saint</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-27140646"/></link></paragraph><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35812844 --><link><caption>Pope Francis recognises Mother Teresa's second 'miracle'</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-35129463"/></link></paragraph><paragraph>Born in 1910 to Albanian parents, Agnese Gonxha Bojaxhiu grew up in what is now the Macedonian capital, Skopje, but was then part of the Ottoman Empire.</paragraph><paragraph>Aged 19, she joined the Irish order of Loreto and in 1929 was sent to India, where she taught at a school in Darjeeling under the name of Therese.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1946 she moved to Kolkata to help the destitute and, after a decade, set up a hospice and a home for abandoned children. </paragraph><paragraph>She founded the Missionaries of Charity in 1950. The sisterhood now has 4,500 nuns worldwide.</paragraph><image id="88777134"/><paragraph>She achieved worldwide acclaim for her work in Kolkata's slums, but her critics accused her of pushing a hardline Catholicism, mixing with dictators and accepting funds from them for her charity.</paragraph><paragraph>Five years after her death, Pope John Paul II accepted a first miracle attributed to Mother Teresa as authentic, clearing the way for her beatification in 2003.</paragraph><image id="88777137"/><paragraph>He judged that the curing of Bengali tribal woman Monica Besra from an abdominal tumour was the result of her supernatural intervention. </paragraph><paragraph>A Vatican commission found that her recovery had been a miracle after the Missionaries of Charity said that the woman had been cured by a photo of the nun being placed on her stomach. The finding was criticised as bogus by rationalist groups in Bengal. </paragraph><paragraph>In December 2015, Pope Francis recognised a second miracle, which involved the healing of a Brazilian man with several brain tumours in 2008. The man's identity was not disclosed but the man was said to have been cured unexpectedly after his priest prayed for Mother Teresa's intervention with God.</paragraph><paragraph>It often takes decades for people to reach sainthood after their death, but beatification was rushed through by Pope John Paul II and Pope Francis was known to be keen to complete the process during the Church's Holy Year of Mercy which runs to November 2016.</paragraph><paragraph>In an unrelated move, the Pope last week introduced new financial rules governing the process of becoming a saint, in response to allegations that some candidates supported by wealthy donors were likely to have their cases resolved faster than others.</paragraph><paragraph>Under the regulations, an administrator must be named for each prospective saint and should "scrupulously respect" the intention of each donation as well as manage the funds donated.</paragraph><paragraph>The cost to the Vatican can be high during the "Roman phase" of the process, when the Congregation for the Causes of Saints investigates the candidate, and there have been claims that officials failed to oversee how some donations were spent.</paragraph></body>
/news/world-europe-35809891.shortFormBody: <shortFormBody xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/b853ebb5-049f-c14c-bfab-98acc7797835"><paragraph>Mother Teresa, the Roman Catholic nun who worked with the poor in the Indian city of Kolkata (Calcutta) is to be declared a saint on 4 September, Pope Francis has announced.</paragraph><paragraph>She founded a sisterhood that runs 19 homes, and won the Nobel Peace Prize.</paragraph><paragraph>She died in 1997 - aged 87 - and was beatified in 2003, the first step to sainthood.</paragraph><paragraph>The Pope cleared the way for sainthood last year when he recognised a second miracle attributed to Mother Teresa.</paragraph></shortFormBody>

/news/world-asia-india-35130795.title: BBC News - Profile: 'Living Saint' Mother Teresa
/news/world-asia-india-35130795.summary: A profile of Mother Teresa, who died in 1997 and is being considered for a sainthood after Pope Francis recognised a second miracle attributed to her.
/news/world-asia-india-35130795.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/0c5de4dd-21c6-2245-8686-f156a17252d4"><image id="87278482"/><paragraph role="introduction">When she was alive, Mother Teresa was called "a living saint". Now, 18 years after her death, she is on the road to officially holding the title.</paragraph><paragraph>Pope Francis has recognised a second miracle attributed to her - the healing of a Brazilian man with several brain tumours in 2008.</paragraph><paragraph>This tiny, wizened figure captured the imagination of the world with her dedication to the poor, particularly in the Indian city of Kolkata (Calcutta) where she established her first shelter to cope with the thousands of "pavement people".</paragraph><paragraph>No matter how destitute, diseased or repellent they might have been, the poor were welcomed. The dying were afforded a dignity in death.</paragraph><paragraph>The order she founded, the Missionaries of Charity, grew to include 3,000 nuns and 400 brothers in 87 countries, tending to the poor and dying in the slums of 160 cities.</paragraph><paragraph>In 1979, she accepted the Nobel Peace Prize on behalf of "the throwaway of society". She asked that the grand gala dinner be cancelled and the proceeds be given to the poor of Kolkata.</paragraph><paragraph>In 2002, five years after her death, <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35130796 --><link><caption>Pope John Paul II judged that the healing of a woman</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/2593073.stm"/></link> suffering from an abdominal tumour was the result of Mother Teresa's supernatural intervention.</paragraph><image id="87280147"/><crosshead>'Call within'</crosshead><paragraph>Mother Teresa was born Agnes Gonxha Bojaxhiu, in 1910 in Skopje, now capital of the Republic of Macedonia, which was then part of the Ottoman Empire. Her family were ethnic Albanians, and devout Catholics.</paragraph><paragraph>She decided as early as 12 that she wanted to become a missionary in India. At the age of 19, she joined the Irish order of Loreto where she was taught English. In 1929 she was sent to India.</paragraph><paragraph>Mother Teresa - she took the name from Therese of Lisieux - began teaching at a school in Darjeeling, a town in the Himalayan foothills. Then, in 1946, amid the communal strife that gripped British-ruled India at the time, she heard her "call within" to help the poor while living among them.</paragraph><paragraph>After 10 years helping the destitute in the slums of Kolkata, where 100,000 were homeless, she expanded by opening a hospice in the grounds of a Hindu temple in Kalighat, followed by a home for abandoned children and a refuge for lepers.</paragraph><image id="87280442"/><crosshead>An ultra conservative</crosshead><paragraph>Her work spread throughout India, and her fame grew with it. In 1970, the journalist Malcolm Muggeridge made a film that brought her to the attention of the West.</paragraph><paragraph>Muggeridge, an agnostic, was inspired to convert to the Catholic faith. "Words cannot convey how beholden I am to her," he wrote.</paragraph><paragraph>Mother Teresa was fervently opposed to contraception and abortion. She told an Oxford conference in 1988 that she would never allow a child entrusted to her care to be adopted by a woman who had an abortion or used contraceptives. "Such a woman cannot love," she said.</paragraph><paragraph>This put her at great odds with the feminist movement. Germaine Greer called her "a religious imperialist". The writer Christopher Hitchens also criticised her for her association with dictators such as the Duvaliers in Haiti and Enver Hoxha in Albania.</paragraph><image id="87280444"/><paragraph>Mother Teresa's view was that if someone offers charity for the poor it should be accepted for their sake regardless of the merits or otherwise of the giver.</paragraph><paragraph>Her hardline views on abortion and contraception were welcomed by the socially conservative Pope John Paul II who used Mother Teresa as a spokesperson for papal causes.</paragraph><paragraph>Mother Teresa, whose only possessions were a bucket and two saris, came to symbolise love for the unloved and care for the unwanted. In the words of Malcolm Muggeridge, she contributed "something beautiful for God".</paragraph></body>
