/news/business-35809196.title: BBC News - Sony buys out Michael Jackson music venture stake
/news/business-35809196.summary: Sony is paying Michael Jackson's estate $750m (£526m) for the late pop star's share of a joint music venture that it does not already own.
/news/business-35809196.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/ee1c2915-c604-b84f-8ef4-820bf6a83988"><image id="88773601"/><paragraph role="introduction">Sony is paying Michael Jackson's estate $750m (£526m) for the late pop star's share of a joint music publishing venture that it does not already own.</paragraph><paragraph>Jackson held a 50% stake in Sony ATV Music Publishing as part of a business partnership that began in 1995.</paragraph><paragraph>The purchase will give Sony the rights to about three million songs, including works by the Beatles, Bob Dylan and Taylor Swift.</paragraph><paragraph>However, the deal does not include Jackson's master recordings.</paragraph><paragraph>His estate will maintain its holdings in Mijac Music, which owns all the songs written by Jackson, as well as EMI Music Publishing.</paragraph><image id="88773291"/><paragraph>The agreement will reportedly help reduce the Jackson estate's remaining $250m debt and give the late musician's three children more financial flexibility.</paragraph><paragraph>The purchase of Jackson's stake also strengthens Sony's US entertainment business, which includes a film studio and music recording company.</paragraph><paragraph>"The entertainment businesses have long been a core part of Sony and are a key driver of our future growth," Kazuo Hirai, Sony's president and chief executive, <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35809197 --><link><caption>said in a statement</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.sony.net/SonyInfo/News/Press/201603/16-0315E/index.html"/></link>.</paragraph><paragraph>"These businesses will continue to contribute to our success for years to come."</paragraph><paragraph>John Branca and John McClain, co-executors of the Jackson estate, said the deal "further validates Michael's foresight and genius in investing in music publishing".</paragraph><paragraph>"His ATV catalogue, purchased in 1985 for a net acquisition cost of $41.5m, was the cornerstone of the joint venture and, as evidenced by the value of this transaction, is considered one of the smartest investments in music history." </paragraph></body>
/news/business-35809196.shortFormBody: <shortFormBody xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/ee1c2915-c604-b84f-8ef4-820bf6a83988"><paragraph>Sony is paying Michael Jackson's estate $750m (£526m) for the late pop star's share of a joint music publishing venture that it does not already own.</paragraph><paragraph>Jackson held a 50% stake in Sony ATV Music Publishing as part of a business partnership that began in 1995.</paragraph><paragraph>The purchase will give Sony the rights to about three million songs, including works by the Beatles, Bob Dylan and Taylor Swift.</paragraph><paragraph>However, the deal does not include Jackson's master recordings.</paragraph></shortFormBody>

/news/technology-35810133.title: BBC News - Google's AI wins final Go challenge
/news/technology-35810133.summary: In the final challenge between man and machine, Google's AI emerges victorious.
/news/technology-35810133.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/78a9c1c8-40f1-c14f-a16a-12aba505c50b"><image id="88775182"/><paragraph role="introduction">Google's DeepMind artificial intelligence has secured its fourth win over a master player, in the final of a five match challenge.</paragraph><paragraph>Lee Se-dol, one of the world's top Go players, won just one of the matches against the AlphaGo program, missing out on the $1m prize up for grabs.</paragraph><paragraph>Demis Hassabis, founder of DeepMind, said the match had been the "most exciting and stressful" for his team.</paragraph><paragraph>Lee Se-dol said he felt "regrettable" about the result of the contest.</paragraph><image id="88775343"/><paragraph>In Go, players take turn placing stones on a 19-by-19 grid, competing to take control of the most territory.</paragraph><paragraph>The game is considered to be much more challenging for computers than chess.</paragraph><paragraph>At a press conference held after the final match, Mr Lee said he did not necessarily think AlphaGo was superior to humans.</paragraph><paragraph>But he said he had more studying to do, and admitted the matches had challenged some of his ideas about the game Go.</paragraph><image id="74982321"/><crosshead>Analysis: Stephen Evans, Seoul correspondent</crosshead><image id="88775345"/><paragraph>In some countries the people watch football on big screens in public squares, but in South Korea it's been the mighty challenge of machine against humanity.</paragraph><paragraph>And the victory of the computer has led to some introspection.</paragraph><paragraph><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35813652 --><link><caption>One South Korean newspaper complained</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/opinon/2016/03/202_200231.html"/></link> that the contest was "lopsided" with the single Korean pitted against the corporate might of Google and its "army of super-smart people armed with unfathomable computing power".</paragraph><paragraph>In a spirit of magnanimity, however, the Korea Baduk Association - which governs the game of Go - has decided to give an honorary ninth-dan ranking to AlphaGo.</paragraph><paragraph>The 4-1 mechanical victory has also made some Go players doubt themselves.</paragraph><paragraph>The European champion who lost last year to AlphaGo said it had really knocked his self-confidence, even as it enabled him to climb up the world rankings.</paragraph><paragraph>Go was invented about 2,500 years or so ago in China. Until now, it has always had a human best player. Not any more.</paragraph><image id="74982321"/><paragraph>The five match challenge began in Seoul on 9 March, where AlphaGo scored its first victory.</paragraph><paragraph>After losing the second match, Lee Se-dol said he was "speechless" adding that the AlphaGo machine played a "nearly perfect game".</paragraph><paragraph>In the third game commentators said that Lee Se-dol had brought his "top game" but that AlphaGo had won "in great style".</paragraph><paragraph>DeepMind's winning streak meant it won the $1m (£702,000) prize on offer. Google said the money would be donated to Unicef, Stem (science, technology, engineering, and maths) charities and Go organisations.</paragraph><paragraph>Mr Hassabis said: "We have been lucky to witness the incredible culture and excitement surrounding Go.</paragraph><paragraph>"Despite being one of the oldest games in existence, Go this week captured the public's attention across Asia and the world."</paragraph><crosshead>Expertise</crosshead><paragraph>The AlphaGo system was developed by British computer company DeepMind which was bought by Google in 2014.</paragraph><paragraph>It has built up its expertise by studying older games and teasing out patterns of play. </paragraph><paragraph>Lee Se-dol did win the fourth match against AlphaGo, after which he said: "I've never been congratulated so much because I've won one game."</paragraph><paragraph>Despite Mr Lee's overall defeat, rival players have still expressed confidence that they could beat the AI.</paragraph><paragraph>Ahead of the final, China's top ranked Go master Ke Jie said he believed he could beat AlphaGo.</paragraph><paragraph>He told China Central Television: "In terms of probability, I have a chance to win, but the probability is not as high as I thought before. I think it is 60 per cent in favour of me."</paragraph><image id="74982321"/><paragraph><bold>Analysis by Dr Noel Sharkey, AI expert</bold></paragraph><paragraph>To beat one of the world's top players, Deep Mind used a mixture of clever strategies to make the search much smaller.</paragraph><paragraph>Does this mean AI is now smarter than us and will kill us mere humans? Certainly not. </paragraph><paragraph>AlphaGo doesn't care if it wins or loses. It doesn't even care if it plays and it certainly couldn't make you a cup of tea after the game. </paragraph><paragraph>Does it mean that AI will soon take your job? Possibly you should be more worried about that.</paragraph><image id="74982321"/><crosshead>What is Go?</crosshead><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="87961898">    <caption>A brief guide to Go</caption>  </video><paragraph>Go is thought to date back to several thousand years ago in China.</paragraph><paragraph>Using black-and-white stones on a grid, players gain the upper hand by surrounding their opponents pieces with their own.</paragraph><paragraph>The rules are simpler than those of chess, but a player typically has a choice of 200 moves, compared with about 20 in chess - there are more possible positions in Go than atoms in the universe, according to DeepMind's team.</paragraph><paragraph>It can be very difficult to determine who is winning, and many of the top human players rely on instinct.</paragraph><image id="74982321"/></body>
/news/technology-35810133.shortFormBody: <shortFormBody xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/78a9c1c8-40f1-c14f-a16a-12aba505c50b"><paragraph>Google's DeepMind artificial intelligence has secured its fourth win over a master player, in the final of a five match challenge.</paragraph><paragraph>Lee Se-dol, one of the world's top Go players, won just one of the matches against the AlphaGo program, missing out on the $1m prize up for grabs.</paragraph><paragraph>Demis Hassabis, founder of DeepMind, said the match had been the "most exciting and stressful" for his team.</paragraph><paragraph>Lee Se-dol said he felt "regrettable" about the result of the contest.</paragraph></shortFormBody>

/news/technology-35810133.headline: Google's AI wins final Go challenge
/news/technology-35810133.shortHeadline: Google's AI wins final Go challenge

/news/technology-35785875.title: BBC News - Artificial intelligence: Google's AlphaGo beats Go master Lee Se-dol
/news/technology-35785875.summary: Google's AlphaGo program wins a competition against a human Go master, in what is seen as a landmark moment for artificial intelligence.
/news/technology-35785875.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/01d82565-5ee8-8a40-b574-3143675bcdef"><image id="88738427"/><paragraph role="introduction">A computer program has beaten a master Go player 3-0 in a best-of-five competition, in what is seen as a landmark moment for artificial intelligence.</paragraph><paragraph>Google's AlphaGo program was playing against Lee Se-dol in Seoul, in South Korea.</paragraph><paragraph>Mr Lee had been confident he would win before the competition started.</paragraph><paragraph>The Chinese board game is considered to be a much more complex challenge for a computer than chess.</paragraph><paragraph>"AlphaGo played consistently from beginning to the end while Lee, as he is only human, showed some mental vulnerability," one of Lee's former coaches, Kwon Kap-Yong, told the AFP news agency.</paragraph><paragraph>Mr Lee is considered a champion Go player, having won numerous professional tournaments in a long, successful career.</paragraph><paragraph>Go is a game of two players who take turns putting black or white stones on a 19-by-19 grid. Players win by taking control of the most territory on the board, which they achieve by surrounding their opponent's pieces with their own.</paragraph><paragraph>In the first game of the series, AlphaGo triumphed by a very narrow margin - Mr Lee had led for most of the match, but AlphaGo managed to build up a strong lead in its closing stages. </paragraph><image id="88738434"/><paragraph>After losing the second match to Deep Mind, Lee Se-dol said he was "speechless" adding that the AlphaGo machine played a "nearly perfect game".</paragraph><paragraph>The two experts who provided commentary for the YouTube stream of for the third game said that it had been a complicated match to follow.</paragraph><paragraph>They said that Lee Se-dol had brought his "top game" but that AlphaGo had won "in great style".</paragraph><paragraph>The AlphaGo system was developed by British computer company DeepMind which was bought by Google in 2014.</paragraph><paragraph>It has built up its expertise by studying older games and teasing out patterns of play. And, according to DeepMind chief executive Demis Hassabis, it has also spent a lot of time just playing the game. </paragraph><paragraph>"It played itself, different versions of itself, millions and millions of times and each time got incrementally slightly better - it learns from its mistakes," he told the BBC before the matches started.</paragraph><paragraph>This virtuous circle of constant improvement meant the super computer went into the five-match series stronger than when it beat the European champion late last year.</paragraph><image id="74982321"/><crosshead>What does this mean for artificial intelligence? Dr Noel Sharkey, AI expert</crosshead><paragraph>Artificial Intelligence (AI) has flirted with games since its beginnings, because only smart humans excel. Unlike the real world, a closed system of fixed rules suits computing. </paragraph><paragraph>Despite critical voices, Arthur Samuel's draughts playing program was an incredible achievement in 1959. Like AlpahGo it learned by playing itself repeatedly only many orders of magnitude slower.</paragraph><paragraph>Then the goal posts moved. The critics said chess was beyond computing's capability because it needed human intuition and creativity. But then when good amateur challengers had to eat their words in the 1970s, the goal post shifted again. </paragraph><paragraph>Critics claimed a horizon where computers might beat some professionals but certainly not grand masters. So when IBM's Deep Blue supercomputer beat world champion Garry Kasparov in 1997, the world was astonished. But Deep Blue was not the human-like intelligence that the founding fathers of AI had hoped for. It won by brute force by searching through millions of moves in seconds. Humans have limited memory and need brilliant pattern perception and creative strategies to win.</paragraph><image id="88730430"/><paragraph>So the critics turned to Go as the impossible. Even with today's vast computer memories and incredibly fast processors (which have doubled more than eight times since Deep Blue), the ancient game will not yield to brute force. The size of the search required for Go is larger than chess by more than the number of atoms in the universe. It is the holy grail of AI gaming.</paragraph><paragraph>When Facebook announced earlier this year that their program had beaten a strong Go amateur, jaws dropped in the AI community - and fell to the floor that same day when Google's Deep Mind genius team announced their AlphaGo beat the European champion 5-0. </paragraph><paragraph>To beat one of the world's top players, Deep Mind used a mixture of clever strategies to make the search much smaller. They trained their machine on 30 million expert moves to start with, and then the learning machine played against itself millions of times. It worked - the holy grail is in the bag and the goal posts can shift no further. </paragraph><paragraph>Does this mean AI is now smarter than us and will kill us mere humans? Certainly not. AlphaGo doesn't care if it wins or loses. It doesn't even care if it plays and it certainly couldn't make you a cup of tea after the game. Does it mean that AI will soon take your job? Possibly you should be more worried about that. </paragraph><image id="74982321"/><crosshead>What is Go?</crosshead><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="87961898">    <caption>A brief guide to Go</caption>  </video><paragraph>Go is thought to date back to several thousand years ago in China.</paragraph><paragraph>Using black-and-white stones on a grid, players gain the upper hand by surrounding their opponents pieces with their own.</paragraph><paragraph>The rules are simpler than those of chess, but a player typically has a choice of 200 moves, compared with about 20 in chess - there are more possible positions in Go than atoms in the universe, according to DeepMind's team.</paragraph><paragraph>It can be very difficult to determine who is winning, and many of the top human players rely on instinct.</paragraph><image id="74982321"/></body>
/news/technology-35785875.shortFormBody: <shortFormBody xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/01d82565-5ee8-8a40-b574-3143675bcdef"><paragraph>A computer program has beaten a master Go player 3-0 in a best-of-five competition, in what is seen as a landmark moment for artificial intelligence.</paragraph><paragraph>Google's AlphaGo program was playing against Lee Se-dol in Seoul, in South Korea.</paragraph><paragraph>Mr Lee had been confident he would win before the competition started.</paragraph><paragraph>The Chinese board game is considered to be a much more complex challenge for a computer than chess.</paragraph></shortFormBody>

/news/blogs-news-from-elsewhere-35812339.title: BBC News - Thailand's overweight monks are put on a diet
/news/blogs-news-from-elsewhere-35812339.summary: Academics and temples plan help for 'ticking time bomb' obese monks.
/news/blogs-news-from-elsewhere-35812339.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/a211ef21-9e09-9e43-81fd-063a44726e14"><image id="88778424"/><paragraph role="introduction">Steps are being taken in Thailand to wean Buddhist monks off unhealthy food after a study suggested that almost half of them are overweight.</paragraph><paragraph>Jongjit Angkatavanich, a health and nutrition expert at Bangkok's Chulalongkorn University, says 48% of monks are obese, <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35812620 --><link><caption>the Bangkok Post reports</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/general/897276/almost-half-monkhood-overweight"/></link>. Her warning that "Obesity in our monks is a ticking time bomb" seems to have given the religious authorities cause for concern, with her figures showing that 42% have high cholesterol levels, 23% suffer from high blood pressure, and over 10% are diabetic. Dr Jongjit didn't say how many monks were involved in a study, but she's helping to roll out a national programme aimed at slimming down Thailand's holy men.</paragraph><paragraph>The government already covers medical fees for monks, who play a prominent part in Thailand's social and religious life, and spent more than 300m baht (£6m; $8.5m) on countering chronic obesity-related problems in 2012 alone, the paper says. Dr Jongjit singles out the sweet drinks and fatty foods that members of the public donate to the monks, and her Faculty of Allied Heath Sciences university is launching a campaign to promote leaner clerical living.</paragraph><paragraph>A monastic college and four temples in Bangkok are pioneering nutritional cooking programmes heavy on fibre, protein and calcium, and encouraging the clerics to take more physical exercise. Dr Jongjit says the monks involved have already lost an average of one kilogram (2.2lb) in weight over eight weeks, cut their waistlines by 1.4cm (half an inch), and seen drops in cholesterol levels. Some monks complain that they don't know how much weight they're putting on, which is why Chulalongkorn Memorial Hospital has launched a special girdle that tightens around the waist as a gentle reminder. </paragraph><paragraph><bold>Next story: </bold><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35812344 --><link><caption>NZ police get bigger handcuffs for larger offenders</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/blogs-news-from-elsewhere-35811093"/></link></paragraph><paragraph><italic>Use #NewsfromElsewhere to stay up-to-date with our reports via </italic><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35812340 --><link><caption>Twitter</caption><url platform="highweb" href="https://twitter.com/search?q=%23NewsfromElsewhere&src=typd"/></link>.</paragraph></body>

/news/election-us-2016-35806377.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/6dbe67f3-bcbc-0843-bb45-f544295fb7f5"><paragraph>US Republican politician Sarah Palin has criticised protesters' "punk-ass thuggery" at a rally for presidential candidate Donald Trump.</paragraph><paragraph>Mrs Palin had previously cancelled her appearance at the campaign event in Florida after news her husband Todd had been injured in a snowmobile crash in Alaska.</paragraph></body>

/news/magazine-35802891.title: BBC News - Were investors conned into buying rare manuscripts?
/news/magazine-35802891.summary: About 18,000 people in France are believed to have been defrauded in one of the biggest ever arts-market scams - they bought shares in rare manuscripts.
/news/magazine-35802891.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/f98ca483-80ad-634e-a35c-06d3bb4bb007"><image id="88761953"/><paragraph role="introduction">About 18,000 people in France are believed to have been defrauded in one of the biggest ever arts-market scams. They bought shares in rare manuscripts and letters to a value of nearly 1bn euros, before the company behind it was shut down by regulators. Now the victims of Aristophil want to know what is left of their investment.</paragraph><paragraph>Up until a few months ago you could visit a place called the Museum of Letters and Documents, on the Boulevard Saint-Germain in the heart of literary Paris.</paragraph><paragraph>Even this morning, Wikipedia English said the museum - with its stock of 130,000 rare manuscripts - was open for business. </paragraph><paragraph>It isn't. What was once the haunt of dreamy youth is now a branch of Bang and Olufsen. The documents are in a warehouse in Seine-Saint-Denis.</paragraph><paragraph>The closure followed the disgrace of a businessman and enthusiast, who over a decade turned the fusty world of French manuscripts and autographs on its head.</paragraph><image id="88761949"/><paragraph>Gerard Lheritier was - for a time - a visionary. He saw in the world of rare letters and documents a market that was seriously undervalued.</paragraph><paragraph>As his lawyer Francis Triboulet puts it, "Lheritier spotted before anyone else did that people adore old documents - anything that lets them come into physical contact with their heroes of the past."</paragraph><paragraph>But today his fortune has been confiscated, his company put into liquidation, while across the country thousands of angry investors are baying for his blood.</paragraph><paragraph>The son of a plumber from eastern France, Lheritier was a self-taught outsider in a field dominated by a handful of Paris dealers. About 15 years ago, he enlisted the help of one of these experts, and began buying.</paragraph><paragraph>One of his early acquisitions was a document called the Einstein-Musso - 54 pages of calculations on the theory of general relativity - which he bought for just over 500,000 euros.</paragraph><image id="88761952"/><paragraph>Lheritier's next step was to become his business model. He divided the Einstein-Musso into 400 "shares", which he sold on to investors.  </paragraph><paragraph>The fact that the total value now amounted to 12m euros - 24 times the amount he had spent - was easily explicable: the market was growing, the investors were in early, and everyone wanted a piece of Einstein.</paragraph><paragraph>Over the years Gerard Lheritier developed his system to become king of the market. His presence at a sale set prices soaring.</paragraph><image id="88761948"/><paragraph>His company Aristophil employed hundreds of sales staff across France, giving "independent" advice about the huge returns awaiting those willing to make the jump.</paragraph><paragraph>Aude Nehring's father was one of those who fell for the lure. Looking for an investment for his children,  he was approached by a broker and placed his 35,000 euros in part-shares in seven Aristophil documents.</paragraph><quoteBox><quote><quoteText>Gerard Lheritier was offering returns - 40% over five years - which he knew were unattainable</quoteText><quoteSource title="Lawyer">Philippe Julien</quoteSource></quote></quoteBox><paragraph>He never saw the documents, but he was assured a return of 8% a year. In the contract, Aristophil reserved the right (but significantly not the obligation) to buy back the shares at the appreciated value.</paragraph><paragraph>Aude's father died two years ago, never realising that his investment was a dud.</paragraph><paragraph>"It makes me so angry to think what Aristophil did," she says. "My father was not a fool.  He was a businessman himself. But somehow they managed to persuade him."</paragraph><paragraph>Something about the cachet of owning historic  documents kept the punters coming.</paragraph><image id="88761954"/><paragraph>And behind the hype there was some reality. Gradually Lheritier was amassing a huge collection of manuscripts - some of which were indeed very valuable: Dead Sea Scrolls, Mozart scores, a Marquis de Sade original.</paragraph><paragraph>France's best-known newsreader Patrick Poivre d'Arvor joined the roadshow, lending the scheme - in the eyes of the public - an adamantine kudos.</paragraph><paragraph>And there were the museums - first in Paris and a second in Brussels - pushing the notion that documents and letters from the past are intrinsically possessed of value.</paragraph><paragraph>But - as the French expression goes - the worm was in the fruit. In November 2014, financial regulators stepped in. Aristophil was defined as a Ponzi-style pyramid scheme, built on false advertising and illusionary market values. Lheritier was charged with fraud, and his vast collection put under lock and key.</paragraph><image id="88767460"/><paragraph>Arguing his defence, lawyer Francis Triboulet told me that yes, things had taken a bad turn in 2013-14 - but it was wrong to say the Aristophil model was inherently fraudulent.</paragraph><paragraph>"The fact is that the investors were acquiring actual items of value - the documents. And still today, they are the owners of those documents! </paragraph><quoteBox><quote><quoteText>They closed down Aristophil on the basis of a hypothetical fraud that might happen in the future</quoteText><quoteSource title="Gerard Lheritier's lawyer">Francis Triboulet</quoteSource></quote></quoteBox><paragraph>"So no-one can even say for certain that they have lost money, because the documents have not been put on the market - and who can say what they are worth?"</paragraph><paragraph>Triboulet says the prosecution of his client is like something out of the science fiction film Minority Report, where crimes can be predicted.</paragraph><paragraph>"They closed down Aristophil on the basis of a hypothetical fraud that might happen in the future. At the time, not one investor had lodged a complaint. I think in court the charge will be very hard to stand up."</paragraph><paragraph>But lawyers representing victims say that the fact of there being assets - the documents - is irrelevant.   </paragraph><paragraph>"Gerard Lheritier was offering returns - 40% over five years - which he knew were unattainable. But he needed the investment to keep coming in," says lawyer Philippe Julien.</paragraph><paragraph>One bizarre twist in the story is that in 2012 - well before the collapse of his company - Gerard Lheritier was the biggest ever winner in France of the EuroMillions lottery, scooping a 170m euro jackpot.</paragraph><paragraph>Absurd though it sounds, there is no evidence to suggest that the win was not genuine.  (Initially there was speculation Lheritier was proclaiming a jackpot in order to mask the origin of part of his wealth).</paragraph><paragraph>According to Francis Triboulet, Lheritier put 40m euros of the new money straight into Aristophil - proof that it was legitimate (otherwise why would he invest so much of his own cash?)</paragraph><paragraph>Meaningless, says the prosecution. Pyramid schemes depend on appearance, so the guilty always spend a fortune.</paragraph><image id="88761951"/><paragraph>Based around half a dozen galleries in the modish Saint-Germain quarter, the world of French manuscripts is today gradually recovering its poise - so rudely shaken by the irruption of the Aristophil <italic>parvenu</italic>.</paragraph><paragraph>"From the start I suspected a fraud. The vulgarity of the publicity was glaring. Hugo up 5% in a year! Baudelaire up 10%!" says dealer Frederic Castaing.</paragraph><paragraph>"But the point is there is no set value for a Victor Hugo letter. It depends on far too many variables. </paragraph><paragraph>"Anyway real collectors aren't that interested in the pecuniary value of a document. They love the touch of it, the sense of communing with a personage who is normally shut up in an encyclopedia.</paragraph><paragraph>"What Lheritier did was turn part of our cultural heritage into stocks and shares. It was detestable."</paragraph><paragraph><italic>Subscribe to the </italic><!-- CPS Asset ID: 35802892 --><link><caption>BBC News Magazine's email newsletter</caption><url platform="highweb" href="https://ssl.bbc.co.uk/newsletters/newsmagazine?ptrt=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine"/></link><italic> to get articles sent to your inbox.</italic></paragraph></body>

/news/world-latin-america-35803496.title: BBC News - Indigenous community in Peru suffers after oil spill
/news/world-latin-america-35803496.summary: BBC South America correspondent Wyre Davies reports from Chiriaco, in northern Peru, where an oil spill has blighted the lives of the indigenous community.
/news/world-latin-america-35803496.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/ed09884e-d406-d446-8737-22c5466922b9"><image id="88764745"/><paragraph role="introduction">Oil and water do not mix, anyone can tell you that.</paragraph><paragraph>It is a basic rule of science, which certainly holds true in the jungles of northern Peru, at the headwaters of the world's greatest river system.</paragraph><paragraph>Not for the first time in recent years, locals have been dealing with the aftermath of a huge oil spill after a trans-Amazonian pipeline fractured, emptying some 3,000 barrels of thick black crude into the jungle river system.</paragraph><paragraph>For the last month, workers from Peru's state-controlled petrol company have been mopping up and scooping up much of the oil that stuck to the ravines and vegetation in the smaller rivers.</paragraph><crosshead>'Inevitable accident'</crosshead><paragraph>No one really knows how much was swept down the River Chiriaco and then into the River Maranon, one of the biggest Amazon tributaries in Peru. </paragraph><image id="88762470"/><paragraph>Nonetheless, officials from PetroPeru were keen to tell us how well the clean up was going. </paragraph><paragraph>The man in charge of the operation is Victor Palomino. He is showing us how thousands of sacks loaded with contaminated earth are being collected and removed for disposal.</paragraph><image id="88764462"/><paragraph>Mr Palomino denies it was a lack of maintenance that caused the 40-year-old pipeline to break, but he admits its unlikely to be the last such incident.</paragraph><paragraph>"Yes, of course there will be accidents, that's inevitable," the site chief tells me as we survey the damaged steel pipeline.</paragraph><paragraph>"But our biggest concern here is to restore the environment to how it was before and to minimise the risk to local communities," he adds.</paragraph><paragraph>This is the second major spill this year in the northern part of Peru's jungle region, not far from the border with Ecuador. </paragraph><crosshead>Risky clean-up</crosshead><paragraph>But, on top of the environmental impact, we came across something equally disturbing: evidence that children from poor, indigenous communities have been involved in the clean-up.</paragraph><image id="88764456"/><paragraph>"With just our bare hands, like this," 14-year-old Naith says and shows me how she and her two younger brothers scooped oil with their bare hands into buckets.</paragraph><paragraph>She says that they were paid about a dollar for each one by company officials. </paragraph><paragraph>Their father, Jaime, says he stopped them once he found out that they and most other children from the village had been gathering oil for the best part of a day.</paragraph><paragraph>"They fell ill with fever and diarrhoea after being sent to the river," says the father of four. His middle son, seven-year-old Osman, is still in hospital. </paragraph><paragraph>Jaime shows me the boy's oil-stained clothes - not for him the protective white suits worn by the company employees.</paragraph><image id="88764460"/><image id="88764458"/><paragraph>In a statement PetroPeru said it explicitly prohibited the employment of children at the operations centre where it did hire local workers to help in the cleanup.</paragraph><paragraph>But the company said it would look into the allegations.</paragraph><crosshead>Long-lasting effects</crosshead><paragraph>Back out on the river, I watched a small army of workers hard at work removing oil-stained vegetation and debris.</paragraph><image id="88764454"/><paragraph>The company insists that no expense and no amount of human effort will be spared to clean up this oil spill within a month. </paragraph><paragraph>But the effects will last much longer. </paragraph><paragraph>There is a state of emergency that means locals cannot use the water or fish in it for four months. </paragraph><paragraph>This is a waterway on which their very lives depend.</paragraph><paragraph>In the indigenous village of Nazareth, where many locals still live in traditional huts and eke out a subsistence living, one woman shows me her ruined, oil-stained fishing nets.</paragraph><crosshead>'Nothing but trouble'</crosshead><paragraph>"It's a disaster for our community," Elemina tells me in her native Achuar language.  </paragraph><image id="88764750"/><paragraph>With part of their land now contaminated, locals say oil has brought nothing but trouble to the region. </paragraph><paragraph>Environmental campaigners who work with Peru's indigenous communities say the combined effect of impunity for the oil companies and a lack of investment in decades-old infrastructure means that the underlying issues are rarely resolved. </paragraph><paragraph>The falling price for oil on global markets means that there is not much new oil exploration going on in the Amazon jungle these days, something that many people welcome. </paragraph><paragraph>The downside is that the smaller oil companies who still operate here do not have the resources or will to update and maintain their existing networks. </paragraph><paragraph>The Maranon and the mighty Amazon it feeds are big enough to cope with a spill of the size we saw in northern Peru but less certain is the future of the small communities which live alongside the riverbanks.</paragraph></body>

/news/world-asia-india-35800452.title: BBC News - Why India has a 'sliver of time' to seize its chances
/news/world-asia-india-35800452.summary: India is at a "very exceptional time" in its complex and chequered history, says historian Sunil Khilnani, and has a brief moment to "seize its chances".
/news/world-asia-india-35800452.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/f857906d-1da3-7349-8c57-94ca9ac02885"><image id="88757095"/><paragraph role="introduction">Is time running out for India?</paragraph><paragraph>It's a rather dire question to ask a historian, but Sunil Khilnani believes that a young, aspirational country like India in a fast-changing world "will have only a sliver of time, a matter of years, in which to seize its chances". </paragraph><paragraph>"After all, the faster history moves, the more likely is one to get left behind," he writes in an updated edition of his influential book, The Idea of India. </paragraph><paragraph>"I do worry. The urgent and immense problems that India faces, make one realise that it has a narrow moment of time and opportunity," Prof Khilnani, author, most recently of Incarnations, which tells the story of the country through 50 remarkable lives over a period of 2,500 years and is the subject of a <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35803140 --><link><caption>new BBC Radio 4 series</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-india-32700958"/></link>, tells me. </paragraph><paragraph>We are sitting in a hotel in Delhi, talking about his new book, India and the world. </paragraph><paragraph>"Times are changing fast. Just 15 years ago, we were living in a much more open global economy which was more welcoming and positive. Now we are living in a much more protective climate, economies and polities are turning inwards, there is a rise of nationalistic politics in Europe and the US." </paragraph><crosshead>'Volatile world'</crosshead><paragraph>Back home, says Prof Khilnani, director of the India Institute at King's College in London, India is facing a formidable <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35800453 --><link><caption>youth bulge</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/06/sunday-review/the-world-has-a-problem-too-many-young-people.html?_r=0"/></link> - every month, a million Indians turn 18, and every year the country needs to provide at least 12 million jobs - and a weakening of institutions, corruption, demagoguery and use of religion in politics.</paragraph><paragraph>"We are living in a very volatile world where we have to take long-term decisions under short-term pressures." </paragraph><paragraph>So the choices India makes about preserving environment, inclusive growth, welfarism and federalism now will have "enormous consequences" and affect the world "because India's footprint is so big globally".</paragraph><paragraph>"If you look at recent history, the real crunch happens in societies which have fared well for a bit, and then plateaued out. If that society has a lot of young people and if you don't have institutional capacity or will to deal with their demands, you are in for social upheaval," says Prof Khilnani.</paragraph><paragraph>"So we are not living in a routine historical moment, we are living quite an exceptional moment where the choices we make will have a major bearing on our future."</paragraph><image id="88759841"/><image id="88759926"/><image id="88759685"/><paragraph>But don't lose faith, he adds, for India has shown the capacity to handle pressures well. </paragraph><paragraph>Remember the pressures and urgency India faced at the time of Independence - the end of World War II, the bloody partition, birth of a nation, religious riots - and "yet, somewhere, there was an ability [among the leaders] to stand back and take a long view".</paragraph><paragraph>"We have been there before. That's something we can draw from our history. Our bleak moments have often ended strengthening us."</paragraph><paragraph>As evidence he points to the darkest moment in India's history, the 22-month emergency rule in the mid-1970s, when the prime minister Indira Gandhi suspended civil liberties, jailed the opposition and muzzled the media. </paragraph><paragraph>"Mrs Gandhi's countermand of democratic principles instilled something important in independent India's public life: it deepened a spirit of dissent, and of civic and legal activism," he writes in Incarnations.</paragraph><crosshead>'Not a new moment'</crosshead><paragraph>So is India living through a similar period of anxiety now, with concerns over a rising tide of Hindu nationalism, intolerance and challenges to free speech? Is a religious majoritarianism threatening the country's foundational commitment to diversity and pluralism?</paragraph><paragraph>"I don't think it is a new moment. We have had periods like this in the last 150 years of our history. It is an ongoing struggle. When we are in the midst of it, it often looks as if it is a turning point. But that's very hard for us to judge, to have that historical perspective."</paragraph><paragraph>This does not mean, however, that people can be complacent, Prof Khilnani says.</paragraph><paragraph>"We have to be engaged in preserving India's plurality with all our energies. At the end of the day, democracy and pluralism are fragile human experiments. And they are also very easy to destroy."</paragraph><image id="88759838"/><paragraph>"Getting the balance right between not exaggerating [the threats] but at the same time being not complacent is  a question of political judgement."</paragraph><paragraph>That is also what his new book seeks to do. </paragraph><crosshead>'Strength of diversity'</crosshead><paragraph>In a history which is "curiously unpeopled" - usually told through dynasties, epochs, religions and castes - Incarnations profiles Indians who battled in the country's past, an "arena of ferocious contest, its dead heroes continually springing back to life and despatched to the frontlines of equally ferocious contemporary cultural and political battles". </paragraph><paragraph>Diversity is India's greatest treasure, he says, and India's complex history riddled with contradictions is not a threat "but something that is enabling".</paragraph><paragraph>"It is unlike the standard 19th Century European nationalism, in which diversity is almost a threat, where you want to homogenise, you want a single culture, language, religion. Whereas for India, diversity has made India distinctive and stronger as a national project.</paragraph><paragraph>"For me one of the ironies is that some of us in India today think our diversity is disabling and want to go back to a provincial European view of nationalism."</paragraph></body>

88759926.caption: Providing jobs to at least 12 million people every year is a challenge

88757095.caption: Sunil Khilnani's new book tells the story of India through 50 remarkable lives

88759838.caption: Diversity is India's greatest strength, says Prof Khilnani

88759841.caption: India will need to make critical choices about the kind of growth it wants to pursue

88759685.caption: There have been concerns over rising intolerance in India
88759685.altText: A demonstrator waves Indian national flag as she takes part in a protest demanding the release of Kanhaiya Kumar, a Jawaharlal Nehru University (JNU) student union leader accused of sedition, in New Delhi, India, February 18, 2016.

/news/world-asia-india-35800452.headline: Why India has a 'sliver of time' to seize its chances

/news/business-35802739.title: BBC News - A look inside China's first finishing school
/news/business-35802739.summary: A look inside Beijing's Institute Sarita, which claims to be China's first finishing school.
/news/business-35802739.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/72ea241e-034a-9246-9e75-be495e654217"><!-- Embedded video --><video media-id="88766637">    <caption>Students learn deportment and the polite way to eat an orange, among other things.</caption>  </video><paragraph role="introduction">In a secluded courtyard, a lesson in deportment is under way. Some female students, each one with a book balanced on her head, are attempting to walk a few steps without the book falling off.  </paragraph><paragraph>One volume crashes to the ground, but most of the students make it to the other side of the space without mishap, to the approval of the smiling instructor.</paragraph><paragraph>But there's an unusual aspect to this class. It is not happening in Europe, home to many of the world's best-known finishing schools. Instead, it is taking place in Beijing.</paragraph><paragraph>Welcome to Institute Sarita, which it claims is China's first finishing school.</paragraph><paragraph>It is the brainchild of Sara Jane Ho. A native of Hong Kong, she went to boarding school and university in the USA.  After working in investment banking, and for a non-governmental organisation (NGO) in China, she spent some time studying at a Swiss finishing school. </paragraph><paragraph>Inspired by what she had learnt, on her return to China she decided to set up a school of her own.</paragraph><image id="88760452"/><paragraph>"Etiquette shouldn't be Chinese or French, it shouldn't be for the rich or for the poor, it should be for everybody," she says. </paragraph><paragraph>"The spirit of etiquette, no matter where in the world, is the same - it's about respect and consideration for other people, and how to put other people at ease around you."</paragraph><crosshead>'Behave properly'</crosshead><paragraph>The school targets an older age group than its European counterparts. It offers two main courses - one for debutantes, and another, offering instruction in how to be a hostess, for married women.</paragraph><paragraph>One of the most important subjects it teaches is deportment. </paragraph><paragraph>"It's about your character, and the feeling you give to others," explains the institute's president, Rebecca Li, who has also attended a Swiss finishing school. </paragraph><paragraph>"You should make people feel you are confident - a person you can trust."</paragraph><paragraph>How you stand, how you sit, how you walk, how you enter a room, how you shake hands - all these things can have an impact on how you are perceived and how others around you feel, according to Ms Li, "so you have to learn how to behave properly".</paragraph><image id="88759882"/><paragraph>Other lessons include the polite way to eat an orange (which involves using a knife and fork), table setting, and dinner party seating arrangements. </paragraph><paragraph>The vast majority of those who attend the school are women. Men occasionally take part in classes aimed at more mature students, such as lessons in dating etiquette, and managing personal relationships.</paragraph><paragraph>Ms Ho believes the fact that there is demand for courses offered by schools like hers is partly a result of the rapid changes happening in Chinese society.  </paragraph><paragraph>She says that women in particular can find it hard to adjust.</paragraph><paragraph>"In the last century Mao said, 'women hold up half the sky'; he liberated women by letting them enter the workforce, and now in the career world, you do see women advancing," she explains.</paragraph><paragraph>"But there's [also] 2,000 years of Confucian values which say 'the woman should be the noble protector of the home, and her place is the home, and to bear children.'"</paragraph><image id="88759909"/><paragraph>She also believes that globalisation is having a big impact, particularly on the wealthy.  </paragraph><paragraph>"Elite Chinese are starting to send their children to boarding school, they're buying property abroad, they're emigrating abroad," she says. </paragraph><paragraph>"They are learning very quickly, and they're becoming a lot more cosmopolitan, which is why etiquette, now more than ever, is very relevant."</paragraph><crosshead>'An investment'</crosshead><paragraph>Her students agree. Candice Li runs her own business, which conducts research into the luxury market. She often travels internationally, and says that she has become more confident in dealing with foreigners after attending the Institute's classes.</paragraph><paragraph>Studying at the school is far from cheap, with a 10-day debutante course costing around £8,500 (€11,000; $12,200).</paragraph><paragraph>But for another student, Chelsea Chen, "how much you pay is not important, it's how much you can get from the course." </paragraph><paragraph>Ms Chen says she regards her attendance as an "investment… for my family… and for everyone surrounding me". She also hopes that, if in the future, she has children, she will be able to pass on what she has learnt to them. </paragraph><image id="88759913"/><paragraph>Institute Sarita is no longer the only player in the market for etiquette training in China, and it is facing increasing competition. How does Ms Ho see the future of her enterprise?</paragraph><paragraph>"In some ways it's kind of a silly little business," she says. "We charge high prices, but the volume is very low… our classes are very small… and our costs are high… but I went to Harvard Business School, and I always think about how can I make this into something bigger?"</paragraph><paragraph>Ms Ho says her role model is Martha Stewart, the American author, TV host and entrepreneur, who "provided a guide for the suburban housewife" on how to cook, decorate, and entertain.  </paragraph><paragraph>"I want to provide the same to the modern day Chinese woman," she says. </paragraph><paragraph>"I want to help her be the best mother that she can be, be the best wife that she can be, …make the home a place where she can invite loved ones and friends; and also [to learn] how to live, in this modern day world."</paragraph></body>

/news/world-us-canada-35722882.title: BBC News - Could Hillary Clinton face the same fate as David Petraeus?
/news/world-us-canada-35722882.summary: After revealing classified information, David Petraeus received a light punishment. What does this mean for Hillary Clinton?
/news/world-us-canada-35722882.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/15b291ac-2dbb-e142-b351-66f7d4de597f"><image id="88772485"/><paragraph role="introduction">Could Hillary Clinton's handling of classified information while secretary of state sink her presidential hopes? </paragraph><paragraph>It's a question that has dogged her campaign for over a year - but opinions are divided over whether the allegations made against her constitute a crime or are just the latest partisan sideshow.</paragraph><paragraph>Perhaps the best way to look at the implications of her case is by considering the context of another high-profile legal drama involving classified documents that was recently resolved - that of former CIA director David Petraeus.</paragraph><paragraph>Petraeus pleaded guilty last year to a misdemeanour offence, mishandling classified information, after being accused of handing notebooks with classified information to his biographer-turned mistress, Paula Broadwell. </paragraph><paragraph>He was fined and placed on probation - a resolution that some have called a slap on the wrist.</paragraph><paragraph>In other cases people who have revealed classified information were sent to prison. In 2009 Stephen Kim, a former government contractor, was sentenced to 13 months for giving classified material to a reporter.</paragraph><image id="88772487"/><paragraph>But Petraeus is a high-profile figure. He has been credited with implementing the US military "surge" in Iraq that helped bring stability to the nation - at least temporarily. When President Barack Obama tapped him to head the CIA in 2011, his name was kicked around by some Republicans as a possible presidential candidate in 2012.</paragraph><paragraph>His celebrated background has led critics to suggest that there is a double-standard in cases involving the mishandling of classified information - one making it less likely that Mrs Clinton will face repercussions for her actions. </paragraph><paragraph>Mrs Clinton used a private server at her house while she was secretary of state, and some of her emails appeared to have contained classified information, though it's unclear whether that information was classified at the time it was sent. Revealing classified information is a crime.</paragraph><paragraph>Yet the offence is treated in different ways, depending upon the circumstances. They're also tough cases to prosecute.</paragraph><paragraph>Government lawyers have to prove an individual knew what he was doing when he revealed classified information, for example, or that she was unusually sloppy when handling the material.</paragraph><image id="88772489"/><paragraph>After initially denying any culpability, Mrs Clinton has acknowledged that using a private server at her house was a mistake. </paragraph><paragraph>"I should have used two email addresses, one for personal matters and one for my work at the State Department," she said on Facebook in September. "I'm sorry about it, and I take full responsibility."</paragraph><paragraph>One of her former aides, Bryan Pagliano, set up the private server at her house. He has reportedly agreed to co-operate with authorities in the investigation. According to the Washington Post, he's been granted immunity.</paragraph><paragraph>Officials refused to talk to me on the record about the matter. "I'll leave it to the leakers," Marc Raimondi, the justice department's national security spokesman says.</paragraph><paragraph>FBI agents may decide to question Mrs Clinton and more of her aides, both current and former, in the coming months.</paragraph><paragraph>The danger for Mrs Clinton's presidential campaign, even if she avoids criminal charges, is that it could play into the perception by some that the former secretary of state can't be trusted.</paragraph><paragraph>For conservatives hoping to defeat her in the general election and break the Democrats' eight-year hold on the Oval Office, that's good news. It also makes any discussion of the legal case fraught with political significance.</paragraph><paragraph>Every twist and turn in the case, such as revelations this week that one individual had agreed to co-operate with a federal investigation, is scrutinised.</paragraph><paragraph>Kurt Volker, a former US ambassador who's now executive director of the McCain Institute, says her actions are potentially worse than anything Petraeus did. </paragraph><paragraph>Though Petraeus willingly revealed classified information to his mistress, Mrs Clinton apparently sent email with classified information through a server without proper safeguards. As Volker sees things, the classified material became vulnerable to hackers.</paragraph><paragraph>"Everybody and their uncle can potentially see that information," he says. "That means Iranians, Chinese, whoever."</paragraph><paragraph>Volker believes she should be punished for her actions and that investigators are doing the right thing in their efforts to find out more about the case. </paragraph><paragraph>But he's sceptical about the outcome.</paragraph><paragraph>He believes that during an election year, with a Democratic administration in power, she's unlikely to be held accountable for what she did.</paragraph><image id="88772875"/><paragraph>FBI agents will pursue it as a criminal matter, he says, but he believes that justice department officials will "take into account the political context" (and that Mrs Clinton is a Democratic candidate for the presidency.) </paragraph><paragraph>His suspicions about political bias in the White House reinforce a universal truth - campaign season is a time of passion, paranoia and fiery rhetoric.</paragraph><paragraph>Few in Washington think that formal charges will be brought against her, however. And if they were, it's hard to see how she'd be sent to prison for committing the same kind of crime for which Petraeus received probation.</paragraph><paragraph>If she is charged and avoids any serious penalty, then FBI agents, federal investigators - and plenty of her political adversaries - would have reason to be angry.</paragraph><paragraph>"But as far as I can see no crimes have been committed," says Steven Aftergood, the director of the Project on Government Secrecy for the Federation of American Scientists. "So I don't see a place for that sort of frustration."</paragraph><paragraph>Like Volker, he sees the issue as political.</paragraph><paragraph>"We've been bombarded with accusations before any indictment has been filed," Aftergood says. "And for that reason it seems like a manufactured controversy."</paragraph><paragraph>And however you see the politics surrounding the case of Mrs Clinton's email, the controversy is bound to continue - at least until the election.</paragraph><paragraph><italic>Follow @Tara_Mckelvey.</italic></paragraph></body>

/news/business-35770490.title: BBC News - Can Indonesia's forest fires be put out for good?
/news/business-35770490.summary: Indonesia's so-called fire season last year was one of the worst on record. But despite all attempts to stop the fires returning this year- they’re back already with a vengeance.
/news/business-35770490.body: <body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:space="preserve" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/e7accd69-3938-0547-8d13-ae0d041a431e"><image id="88631381"/><paragraph role="introduction">Indonesia's so-called fire season last year was one of the worst on record, but the fires are back and burning out of control with a state of emergency already declared in one province.  </paragraph><paragraph>Between about June and October, more than 100,000 fires burned down millions of hectares of fragile forest lands. </paragraph><paragraph>There were human and animal fatalities, and the economic damage was estimated to be more than $15bn (£10bn). </paragraph><paragraph>For more than 20 years these fires have been an annual occurrence, as farmers and agricultural companies clear Indonesia's forests and carbon-rich peatlands to make way for pulpwood, palm oil and rubber plantations, or for smaller scale subsistence farming. </paragraph><paragraph>But the fires have been getting gradually worse. Last year, the fires were so bad, that parts of Indonesia, together with cities across South East Asia, were blanketed in a thick toxic haze for weeks at a time. </paragraph><image id="85573481"/><paragraph>Half a million people were hospitalised due to the haze, and it was estimated that in those five months about 1.7 billion tonnes of carbon - roughly equivalent to what Brazil produces in a year - had been released into the atmosphere.</paragraph><paragraph>Indonesia promised that it would do more to prevent the fires from returning in 2016.</paragraph><paragraph>But the fires are back already  - and now burning out of control. </paragraph><paragraph>A state of emergency has been declared in the western province of Riau, on the Indonesian island of Sumatra, and the army and police have been called in to try to fight the blazes. </paragraph><image id="88046074"/><paragraph>So what more can the Indonesian government do? </paragraph><crosshead>What is causing the fires?</crosshead><paragraph>Indonesia's government owns the majority of the country's forest land. It provides grants or concessions to small scale farmers and to large companies.</paragraph><paragraph>In the 1980s burning forest areas to clear land for agriculture was sanctioned by the government, and today Indonesia has the highest rate of deforestation in the world.</paragraph><image id="86325052"/><paragraph>For the last two decades, however, it has been against the law to clear more than two hectares of land each year, and using slash-and-burn methods for clearing is illegal.</paragraph><paragraph>But large companies have been accused of paying off small farmers for the use of their concession land - sometimes with just cigarettes and clothes - and then asking those small farmers to clear it for them. </paragraph><image id="75306515"/><crosshead>What is 'slash-and-burn'?</crosshead>  <list type="unordered">    <listItem>Farmers cut down forests and wild plants on their land, then set a fire to clear what remains</listItem>  </list>  <list type="unordered">    <listItem>It is cheap and quick and some farmers believe they are ridding their land of diseases that could hurt their crops</listItem>  </list>  <list type="unordered">    <listItem>Fires to clear land can spark wild fires and spread to carbon-rich peatlands</listItem>  </list>  <list type="unordered">    <listItem>The peat fires release vast amounts of carbon emissions </listItem>  </list><image id="75306515"/><crosshead>How has Indonesia tackled its fires in the past?</crosshead><paragraph>Policing the companies and small farmers responsible for lighting fires has been a huge challenge, and the forestry industry is often described as being riddled with corruption. </paragraph><paragraph>Last year President Joko Widodo told the BBC that he had <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35787445 --><link><caption>gone to great lengths</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-34387979"/></link> to tackle the fires, including the deployment of more than 10,000 police and soldiers and water-bombing planes.</paragraph><image id="85573986"/><image id="85804719"/><paragraph>And Mr Widodo said further development of peatlands would be banned, and that, where possible, his country's carbon-rich lands should be restored.</paragraph><paragraph>But he also told the BBC it would take <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35770555 --><link><caption>at least three years</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-34387979"/></link> before the world would see significant improvements as a result of on-going efforts to control the fires.</paragraph><paragraph>When the fires restarted this year, Henry Purnomo, a scientist who works at the Centre for International Forestry Resarch (Cifor), an organisation which works closely with the government, said Indonesia was employing some of its best fire-prevention efforts to date. He says while the fires are not yet very big "we will need to move fast to suppress those fires burning now".</paragraph><crosshead>What is the government doing now?</crosshead><paragraph>Cifor's Mr Purnomo said environmental workers were out in the field doing their best to rehabilitate about 600,000 hectares of precious peatlands  - with the aim of restoring some two million hectares in the coming years. </paragraph><paragraph>"There is a lot of important work being done by the government as well as the private sector, including the giant companies and the wood plantation companies - they are trying to work together," he said. </paragraph><paragraph>"And President Jokowi has said regional chiefs of police will be replaced if there are ongoing fires in their region."</paragraph><paragraph>In December last year, Indonesia announced that <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35770491 --><link><caption>more than 50 companies</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-35153050"/></link> would be punished for their role in the fires  - and that further investigations were taking place.  </paragraph><paragraph>Just weeks later, however, <!-- CPS Asset ID: 35770492 --><link><caption>a $565m lawsuit</caption><url platform="highweb" href="http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-35203609"/></link> against one plantation company was rejected due to lack of evidence. </paragraph><image id="85574726"/><paragraph>However Mr Purnomo said Indonesia's government was continuing to investigate companies with questionable operations.</paragraph><paragraph>But there still are concerns that directives from central government may be ignored locally. </paragraph><paragraph>Meanwhile, Indonesia's anti-corruption commission said it was encouraging local government agencies in affected areas to come together on prevention efforts and report illegal behaviour to the authorities.</paragraph><paragraph>But Dian Patria, acting director of research and development at Indonesia's Corruption Eradication Commission, says the biggest challenge is that no-one wants to be held responsible for the decades-old problem.</paragraph><paragraph>"There has been bad governance and bad management of the forests, based on our study of the last 12 years, and everyone says it is the fault of the previous minister, or previous governor," says Mr Patria. </paragraph><paragraph>"There are a lot of stakeholders - local government, public and also the licensees - they must be less corrupt and work with us to solve it right now. The private sector especially has to be responsible." he added.</paragraph><paragraph>"Many of the companies you must realise are based in Singapore and Malaysia too. They are not just Indonesian companies."</paragraph><crosshead>What more could be done?</crosshead><paragraph>Peter Holgrem, head of Cifor told the BBC that his teams are developing longer-term programmes to improve the situation. </paragraph><paragraph>But he said there were no quick or easy solutions.</paragraph><image id="85573477"/><paragraph>"It's not a matter of putting the fires out today - it's a matter of changing how land is being used, how agriculture is being practised and how the opportunities for people's livelihood are developing," he said. </paragraph><paragraph>Mr Holmgren, who is based in Indonesia, but works across 45 countries in fire prevention and research, also said it was not just about providing aid to Indonesia or to poor farmers. </paragraph><paragraph>"It's obviously now primarily a matter of domestic policies and domestic regulations," he said.</paragraph><paragraph>"But... a lot of the activities that are going on are because there are investments in land conversion and development - and obviously those investments engage international financial institutions in different ways.</paragraph><paragraph>"So there are probably opportunities in looking at how the international finance system is regulating itself. And to look at the standards around which investments by large international institutions are being made."</paragraph><crosshead>Short and long-term targets </crosshead><image id="86492845"/><paragraph>International forestry and fire fighting experts say one of the biggest problems facing Indonesia is its lack of fire-fighting know-how, particularly at a local level.</paragraph><paragraph>And fire prevention expert Tony Bartlett says wildfires, particularly forest fires, are an increasing problem as the impact of climate change increases.</paragraph><paragraph>Mr Bartlett who works for Australia's Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR) says the international community can support Indonesia in tackling the blazes.</paragraph><image id="88693750"/><paragraph>He argues it is essential to quickly detect and respond to forest fires "with people that are well trained, properly managed and coordinated, and who can deal with different types of forest fires."</paragraph><paragraph>"But it's very difficult when you have peatland on fire," he said. "Forest fires look easy by comparison."</paragraph><image id="88693749"/><paragraph>In the longer term, Cifor's head Mr Holmgren says one solution would be to take agriculture away from peatland completely. </paragraph><paragraph>But he argues the root of the problem is the income insecurity of poor farmers and that tackling that should be the priority.</paragraph><paragraph>"The target is poverty," he says. </paragraph><paragraph>"The target is economic growth and inclusive green growth. And the target is food security," he added.</paragraph><paragraph>"If the issue is isolated to and portrayed as a climate change matter - and that's the story that everyone is hearing - then that is missing the target."</paragraph></body>

items.headline: Can Indonesia's forest fires be put out for good?

88773030.caption: More than 200 orangutans were evacuated after the 2015 fires spread to their forest reserve
88773030.altText: This handout photo taken on 1 October 2015 and released on 9 October 2015 by the Borneo Orangutan Survival Foundation shows babysitter Rusdiani (L) holding baby orangutan Sali in the remaining area once called "the Arboretum", a 159-hectare bit of land planted with various species of trees for the purpose of research and preservation at the Samboja Lestari Orangutan Reintroduction Program in Samboja, in Indonesia's East Kalimantan.

items.summary: Indonesia's so-called fire season last year was one of the worst on record. But despite all attempts to stop the fires returning this year- they’re back already with a vengeance.

/arabic/sports/2016/03/160314_football_l.summary: سجل الياباني شينجي اوكازاكي هدف الفوز لفريق ليستر سيتي  على ضيفه نيوكاسل يونايتد في الدقيقة 25 ليستمر فارق النقاط بين ليستر سيتي وأقرب منافسيه على بطولة البريميير ليغ 5 نقاط.
/arabic/sports/2016/03/160314_football_l.body:
<body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/6168fc1e-ea35-11e5-a22f-c0c33db9bd6e">
         
	
        <image id="d5e365"/>
    









<paragraph role="introduction">عزز ليستر سيتي من صدارته لجدول ترتيب بطولة الدوري الانجليزي الممتاز "البريميير ليغ" بعد فوزه في مباراة الأسبوع رقم 30 على ضيفه نيوكاسل يونايتد بهدف واحد مقابل لاشيء.</paragraph><paragraph>وسجل الياباني شينجي اوكازاكي هدف المباراة في الدقيقة 25 وحافظ الفريق على فارق الهدف حتى النهاية ليستمر فارق النقاط بين ليستر سيتي وأقرب منافسيه على بطولة البريمييرل ليغ 5 نقاط.</paragraph><paragraph>وتحصل ليستر سيتي على 63 نقطة من 30 مباراة خاضها في البطولة بينما جمع ملاحقه توتنهام هوتسبير اللندني 58 نقطة من عدد المباريات ذاته يليهم أرسنال برصيد 52 نقطة من 29 مباراة.</paragraph><paragraph>وكانت المباراة هي الاولى للمدير الفني الإسباني رافاييل بنيتيز مع فريق نيوكاسل خلفا للمدير الفني السابق ستيف ماكلارين.</paragraph><paragraph>وتعتبر هذه رابع هزيمة على التوالي لنيوكاسل الذي خسر 17 مباراة هذا الموسم وجمع 24 نقطة ويقبع في المركز قبل الأخير في جدول الترتيب المكون من 20 فريقا.</paragraph><paragraph>ويتبقى 8 جولات فقط على نهاية البطولة هذا الموسم.</paragraph>
	</body>
/arabic/sports/2016/03/160314_football_l.headline: ليستر سيتي يعزز صدارته للدوري الإنجليزي الممتاز لكرة القدم
/arabic/sports/2016/03/160314_football_l.shortHeadline: ليستر سيتي يعزز صدارته للدوري الإنجليزي الممتاز لكرة القدم

/arabic/sports/2016/03/160313_football_z.summary: نجم السويد ونادي باريس سان جرمان زلاتان ابراهيموفيتش يقول إنه مصمم على الانتقال من النادي الباريسي نهاية الموسم، ولكنه اضاف مازحا اذا صنع له الباريسيون تمثالا ووضعوه مكان برج ايفل، طبعا سيبقى في النادي الفرنسي.
/arabic/sports/2016/03/160313_football_z.body:
<body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/9a307b7a-e97d-11e5-aad6-04b53db9bd6e">
         
	
        <image id="d5e372"/>
    









<paragraph role="introduction">قال نجم السويد ونادي باريس سان جرمان زلاتان ابراهيموفيتش إنه مصمم على الانتقال من النادي الباريسي نهاية الموسم، ولكنه اضاف مازحا اذا صنع له الباريسيون تمثالا ووضعوه مكان برج ايفل، طبعا سيبقى في النادي الفرنسي.</paragraph><paragraph>وكان ابراهيموفيتش سجل هدفه الـ 100 في دوري الدرجة الاولى الفرنسي في المباراة التي حطم فيها بي اس جي فريق تروي 9-0 يوم الاحد وفاز ببطولة الدوري للسنة الرابعة على التوالي.</paragraph><paragraph>وقال ابراهيموفيتش عقب تسجيله 4 اهداف في مرمى تروي الذي يحل في الموقع الاخير في الدوري "الحال الآن اني لن اكون في بي اس جي في الموسم المقبل"، ثم اردف مازحا "اما اذا صنعوا لي تمثالا ووضعوه مكان برج ايفل فطبعا سابقى."</paragraph><paragraph>وينتهي عقد ابراهيموفيتش مع بي اس جي نهاية الموسم الحالي، وبينما ما زال نفوذه في النادي قوي جدا يبدو مستقبله في مهب الريح.</paragraph><paragraph>وترغب ادارة النادي ببقاء ابراهيموفيتش في صفوف بي اس جي، كما يرغب بذلك لاعبوه، وابقى رئيس النادي ناصر الخليفي باب البقاء مفتوحا امامه إذ قال لشبكة كانال بلوس "باريس هي السحر بعينه، وايبرا هو السحر بعينه. فهو لاعب عظيم، واعلم ان كل النوادي تريده. ولكننا نريده ان يبقى معنا، ونريد التحدث اليه."</paragraph><paragraph>وقال مدافع بي اس جي البرازيلي دافيد لويز "سأكون سعيدا اذا بقي هنا، فهو ليس كبير السن بعد."</paragraph><paragraph>وكان ابراهيموفيتش قد سجل هدفا في مرمى تشيلسي اللندني في المباراة التي اقصت الاخير من دوري ابطال اوروبا يوم الاربعاء الماضي.</paragraph><paragraph>وبتسجيله الهدف الثاني في مرمى تروي الاحد، اصبح رصيد ابراهيموفيتش البالغ من العمر 34 عاما من الاهداف 100 في 115 مباراة بدوري الدرجة الاولى الفرنسي.</paragraph><paragraph>وقال لاعب المنتخب السويدي لكانال بلوس "نحن نفوز بكل شيء لاربع سنوات تقريبا. لا اعلم الى متى سيستمر هذا الوضع، ولكني استمتع بوقتي."</paragraph><paragraph>وكان ابراهيموفيتش سجل 27 هدفا في 24 مباراة بالدوري هذا الموسم، اي اكثر بـ 13 هدفا مما سجله زميله في النادي ادينسون كافاني.</paragraph><paragraph>وبهذا النصر في الدوري يكون ابراهيموفيتش قدتوج بـ 13 بطولة إذ فاز بدوري الدرجة الاولى الفرنسي 4 مرات ودوري لا ليغا الاسباني مرة واحدة (مع برشلونه) ودوري سيري أ الايطالي ست مرات (مع 3 نواد) والدوري الهولندي مرتين (مع اياكس امستردام).</paragraph>
	</body>

d5e372.caption: ينتهي عقد ابراهيموفيتش مع بي اس جي نهاية الموسم الحالي

/arabic/sports/2016/03/160313_football_z.headline: ابراهيموفيتش: اذا صنعوا لي تمثالا ووضعوه مكان برج ايفل، طبعا سأبقى في باريس
/arabic/sports/2016/03/160313_football_z.shortHeadline: ابراهيموفيتش: اذا صنعوا لي تمثالا ووضعوه مكان برجل ايفل، طبعا سأبقى في باريس

/arabic/sports/2015/06/150612_football_z.summary: نجم نادي باريس سان جرمان والمنتخب السويدي زلاتان ابراهيموفيتش ينفي ما يتردد عن عزمه الانتقال الى نادي أيه سي ميلان، ويؤكد أنه سعيد بمواصلة اللعب في صفوف ناديه الحالي.
/arabic/sports/2015/06/150612_football_z.body:
<body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/b985b226-1109-11e5-b005-2d943db9bd6e">
         
	
        <image id="d5e372"/>
    









<paragraph role="introduction">نفى نجم نادي باريس سان جرمان والمنتخب السويدي زلاتان ابراهيموفيتش ما يتردد عن عزمه الانتقال الى نادي أيه سي ميلان، ويؤكد أنه سعيد بمواصلة اللعب في صفوف ناديه الحالي.</paragraph><paragraph>وقال ابراهيموفيتش للصحفيين قبيل لقاء المنتخب السويدي مع نظيره من الجبل الأسود في نطاق تصفيات بطولة أوروبا الاحد المقبل "أنا سعيد في بي أس جي، ولا أعلم من أين تختلقون هذه القصص."</paragraph><paragraph>وأصر ابراهيموفيتش البالغ من العمر 33 عاما، والذي شارك في تحقيق باريس سان جرمان الرباعية الفرنسية في الموسم الماضي على أنه "لاعب باريسي، وما زال عقده ساريا لسنة أخرى."</paragraph><paragraph>وقال "الاعلام يضخم الأمور دائما، ولكن لا صحة لما يقال عن انتقالي الى ميلان."</paragraph><paragraph>ولكنه اعترف ضمنا بأن النقلة الى النادي الايطالي، الذي لعب بصفوفه بنجاح بين سنتي 2010 و2012  لا يمكن نفيها قطعيا، إذ قال "كل شيء ممكن."</paragraph>
	</body>
/arabic/sports/2015/06/150612_football_z.headline: ابراهيموفيتش ينفي الاشاعات القائلة إنه سينتقل الى أيه سي ميلان
/arabic/sports/2015/06/150612_football_z.shortHeadline: ابراهيموفيتش ينفي الاشاعات القائلة إنه سينتقل الى أيه سي ميلان

/arabic/sports/2016/03/160309_chelsea_te.summary: فريق باريس سان جيرمان الفرنسي يفوز  على تشيلسي الإنجليزي بهدفين لهدف في مباراة إياب دور الـ 16 من دوري أبطال أوروبا، ويتأهل على حسابه للموسم الثاني على التوالي.
/arabic/sports/2016/03/160309_chelsea_te.body:
<body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/4290f182-e5d7-11e5-82af-e5f43db9bd6e">
         
	
        <image id="d5e375"/>
    









<paragraph role="introduction">فاز فريق باريس سان جيرمان الفرنسي على تشيلسي الانجليزي في لندن، بهدفين لهدف واحد، في مباراة الإياب من الدور الـ16 في دوري أبطال أوروبا</paragraph><paragraph>وتقدم الضيوف في الدقيقة 16 من المباراة، عندما مرر زلاتان إبراهيموفيتش كرة عرضية إلى رابيو، الذي أسكنها شباك الحاري ثيبو كورتوا، ويعطي التفوق لباريس سان جيرمان بثلاثة أهداف لواحد في المبارتين.</paragraph><paragraph>ورد تشيلسي بهدف التعادل عن طريق دييغو كوستا بمجهود فردي متميز في الدقيقة 27 من المباراة.</paragraph><paragraph>ولكن إبراهيموفيتش كان في استقبال توزيعة أنخيل دي ماريا من الجناح الأيسر، وسجل هدف الفوز لفريقه في الدقيقة 67.</paragraph><paragraph>وأحكم باريس سان جيرمان السيطرة على اللعب طيلة الشوط الثاني، وكاد أن يعمق الفارق في أكثر من مناسبة، بينما اصطدمت محاولات وليان وإيدن خازار، الذي خرج متأثرا بإصابة، كلها بدفاع قوي يقوده البرازيليان ديفيد لويز، وثياغو سيلفا.</paragraph><paragraph>ويتأهل باريس سان جيرمان إلى دور الـ 8  من دوري أبطال أوروبا، على حساب تشيلسي للمرة الثانية على التوالي.</paragraph><paragraph>وكانت المباراة الأولى انتهت في باريس بفوز النادي الفرنسي بهدفين لهدف أيضا، سجل فيها لباريس سان جيرمان، زلاتان إبراهيموفيتش، وإيدسون كافان، بينما سجل لتشيلسي جون أوبي ميكال.</paragraph>
	</body>

/arabic/sports/2016/03/160314_nadal_fren.summary: لاعب التنس الأسباني رافاييل نادال يعتزم رفع دعوى قضائية على وزيرة فرنسية سابقة زعمت تناوله للمنشطات، ويؤكد أنه لن يغض الطرف عن مثل هذه المزاعم مستقبلا.
/arabic/sports/2016/03/160314_nadal_fren.body:
<body xmlns="http://www.bbc.co.uk/asset" xml:base="http://www.bbc.co.uk/article/99178f54-e9e5-11e5-ae65-62f03db9bd6e">
         
	
        <image id="d5e375"/>
    









<paragraph role="introduction"> يعتزم لاعب التنس الأسباني رافاييل نادال رفع دعوى قضائية على وزيرة فرنسية سابقة قالت إن غيابه الذي استمر سبعة أشهر في عام 2012 كان "على الأرجح بسبب اختبار إيجابي لتناوله منشطات".</paragraph><paragraph>وشعر نادال بانزعاج شديد لهذه التصريحات التي أدلت بها روزيلين باشيلو، التي كانت وزيرة للصحة والرياضة في فرنسا سابقا.</paragraph><paragraph>وقال نادال، الفائز بـ14 لقبا في بطولة غراند سلام، إنه سيقاضي أي شخص آخر سيزعم "شيئا مشابها في المستقبل".</paragraph><paragraph>وقال نادال إنه سئم من هذه المزاعم، ولم يعد مستعدا لأن يتركها تمر دون اتخاذ إجراء.</paragraph><paragraph>وأضاف: "الوزير في الحكومة الفرنسية يجب أن يكون جادا. وهذا هو التوقيت (الذي يجب) التحرك ضدها، إننا سنقاضيها."</paragraph><paragraph>وتابع: "هذه ستكون المرة الأخيرة (لهذه المزاعم) لأنني سأقاضيها. لقد سئمت من هذه الأشياء، لقد تجاهلت ذلك مرات قليلة في الماضي، ولن أسمح بها ثانية."</paragraph><paragraph>وشغلت باشيلو (69 عاما) منصب وزيرة الصحة والرياضة خلال الفترة من 2007 وحتى 2010 في ظل حكومة الرئيس السابق نيكولا ساركوزي.</paragraph><paragraph>وأدلت بهذه المزاعم بشأن نادال خلال حديثها عن فشل لاعبة التنس الروسية الشهيرة ماريا شارابوفا في اختبارات المنشطات.</paragraph><paragraph>وقالت الوزيرة الفرنسية السابقة: "حينما ترى لاعب تنس يتوقف (عن اللعب) لأشهر، فإن ذلك يعود في الواقع إلى نتيجة إيجابية (لاختبار الكشف عن المنشطات)"</paragraph><paragraph>وكان نادال تحدث بالفعل عن التكهنات المحيطة به.</paragraph>
	
        <image id="d5e403"/>
    









<paragraph>وعقب اعتراف شارابوفا الأسبوع الماضي بفشلها في اجتياز اختبارات المنشطات، علق لاعب التنس المصنف الأول عالميا سابقا بالقول: "إنني رجل نظيف تماما."</paragraph><paragraph>وأضاف: "لم يكن لدي مطلقا إغراء ارتكاب شيء خطأ."</paragraph><paragraph>ولم يفشل نادال مطلقا في اختبارات المنشطات، لكنه كان عرضة لتكهنات بتناوله المنشطات.</paragraph><paragraph>وكان يانيك نوح، الذي فاز سابقا ببطولة فرنسا المفتوحة، كتب مقالا في إحدى الصحف قال فيه إن نجاح اللاعب الأسباني نادال في ملاعب التنس يعود إلى تناوله المنشطات.</paragraph><paragraph>وبعد عام، عرض برنامج تلفزيوني فرنسي ساخر، شخصا بحجم نادال وهو يملأ خزان الوقود في سيارته من مثانته قبل أن توقفه شرطة المرور لتجاوز السرعة المقررة، في تلميح لتناوله المنشطات.</paragraph><paragraph>وعلى نفس المنوال، تساءل اللاعب البلجيكي السابق كريستوف روتشوس في عام 2013 كيف كان بإمكان نادال الفوز ببطولة فرنسا المفتوحة عام 2012، ثم تعرضه للإصابة بعدها بأسبوعين في ويمبلدن.</paragraph>
	</body>
